- Creates a temporary exclusion (2025–2028) from the personal interest disallowance rule for "qualified passenger vehicle loan interest" under IRC §163(h)(4).
- Defines qualified interest as interest on loans (first lien) for personal-use vehicles purchased after Dec 31, 2024, excluding fleet, commercial, lease, salvage, or scrap vehicles.
- Requires vehicle VIN reporting on tax returns to claim the deduction.
- Limits deductible interest to $10,000 annually.
- Phases out deduction for taxpayers with modified AGI over $100,000 (single) or $200,000 (joint), reducing the deduction by $200 per $1,000 over the threshold.
- Allows deduction for non-itemizers under §63(b)(7).
- Requires lenders receiving $600+ in interest annually from individuals to file information returns (new §6050AA), including loan and vehicle details.
- Mandates furnishing of statements to borrowers by Jan 31 following the reporting year.
- Adds penalties for noncompliance under §6724(d).
- Conforms §56(e)(1)(B) to reflect paragraph renumbering in §163(h).

2. Dollar Amounts:
- $10,000 annual cap on deductible interest.
- Deduction reduced by $200 per $1,000 of modified AGI above $100,000 (single) or $200,000 (joint).
- Reporting threshold set at $600 in interest received per calendar year.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Creates a temporary tax incentive for personal vehicle purchases via interest deductibility.
- Encourages purchase of U.S.-assembled vehicles under 14,000 lbs.
- Increases administrative and reporting requirements for lenders.
- Expands IRS data collection and compliance enforcement related to vehicle loans.
- May shift consumer financing behavior toward qualifying loans and vehicles.

sections.section: SEC. 70204. TRUMP ACCOUNTS AND CONTRIBUTION PILOT PROGRAM.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 2--DELIVERING ON PRESIDENTIAL PRIORITIES TO PROVIDE NEW MIDDLECLASS TAX RELIEF
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Establishes "Trump Accounts" as a new type of tax-advantaged individual retirement account (IRA) for minors under age 18, treated similarly to traditional IRAs but with specific restrictions.
- Contributions are limited to $5,000 annually per account (indexed for inflation after 2027), with no tax deduction allowed for contributions made before the beneficiary turns 18.
- Distributions generally prohibited before age 18, with exceptions for rollovers to other Trump Accounts or ABLE accounts.
- Contributions can be made by individuals, employers, or through government/private general funding contributions.
- Employer contributions up to $2,500 per employee per year (indexed for inflation after 2027) are excluded from employee gross income if made under a qualifying Trump Account Contribution Program.
- Qualified general contributions from government or 501(c)(3) organizations are excluded from gross income of the account beneficiary.
- A Trump Accounts Contribution Pilot Program provides a $1,000 refundable credit per eligible child (born 2025–2028) deposited into a Trump Account upon election by a parent.
- Trustees must report contributions, distributions, and account values to the IRS and beneficiaries.
- Penalties established for fraudulent or negligent claims under the pilot program.
- Trump Accounts are restricted to low-cost, non-leveraged mutual or exchange-traded funds tracking broad U.S. equity indices.
- Contributions and distributions are subject to specific coordination rules with existing IRA provisions.
- Trump Accounts cease to exist upon the death of the beneficiary before age 18, with tax consequences for heirs.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- Annual contribution limit: $5,000 per account (indexed after 2027).
- Employer contribution exclusion limit: $2,500 per employee (indexed after 2027).
- Pilot program refundable credit: $1,000 per eligible child.
- Appropriation: $410 million to the Department of the Treasury, available through FY2034.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Creates a new tax-advantaged savings vehicle for minors, potentially increasing early-life investment and savings.
- Encourages employer and philanthropic contributions to youth savings accounts.
- May increase administrative burden on IRS and financial institutions due to new reporting and compliance requirements.
- Could reduce federal revenue due to tax exclusions for contributions and pilot program credits.
- May incentivize early financial planning and investment for children, with long-term effects on wealth accumulation and financial literacy.
- Potential for increased complexity in tax filings and enforcement related to contribution limits, eligibility, and improper claims.

sections.section: SEC. 70301. FULL EXPENSING FOR CERTAIN BUSINESS PROPERTY.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent U.S. Business Tax Reform and Boosting Domestic Investment
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Makes 100% bonus depreciation under IRC §168(k) permanent by eliminating the phase-down schedule and replacing “applicable percentage” with “100 percent.”
- Removes sunset date for certain plant property by allowing bonus depreciation for all plants "planted or grafted," regardless of date.
- Eliminates or consolidates various subclauses in §168(k)(2)(A), (B), and (E), simplifying the definition and treatment of qualified property, including self-constructed and long-production-period property.
- Removes transitional phase-out provisions in §168(k)(6) and §168(k)(8).
- Adds a new transitional election for property placed in service in the first taxable year ending after January 19, 2025, allowing taxpayers to elect reduced bonus depreciation rates: 40% for general qualified property and 60% for long-production-period or transportation property; 40% for specified plants.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- Sets bonus depreciation at 100% for all qualified property acquired and placed in service after January 19, 2025.
- Transitional election allows for 40% or 60% depreciation in lieu of 100% for one year only (taxable year ending after January 19, 2025).

3. Downstream Effects:
- Increases immediate expensing for capital investments, potentially accelerating deductions and reducing taxable income for businesses.
- Simplifies compliance and planning by removing phasedown schedules and date-based eligibility criteria.
- May reduce federal tax revenues in the short term due to increased upfront deductions.
- Encourages investment in long-term and self-constructed assets by maintaining full expensing treatment.
- Transitional election provides flexibility for taxpayers concerned about income smoothing or timing of deductions.

sections.section: SEC. 70302. FULL EXPENSING OF DOMESTIC RESEARCH AND EXPERIMENTAL EXPENDITURES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent U.S. Business Tax Reform and Boosting Domestic Investment
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Creates new IRC §174A allowing immediate deduction of domestic research or experimental (R&E) expenditures, overriding capitalization rules under §263.
- Defines "domestic R&E expenditures" as those not attributable to foreign research under §41(d)(4)(F).
- Taxpayers may elect to amortize certain domestic R&E expenditures over a self-selected period (minimum unspecified months), starting when benefits are realized.
- Software development costs are explicitly treated as domestic R&E expenditures.
- Excludes land acquisition/improvement and mineral exploration costs from §174A treatment.
- Amends §174 to apply only to foreign R&E expenditures, requiring 15-year amortization.
- Updates multiple IRC sections (e.g., §§41, 56, 59, 263, 280C) to coordinate with §174A, distinguishing between domestic and foreign R&E.
- Allows certain small businesses to retroactively apply §174A to tax years beginning after December 31, 2021.
- Permits deduction of unamortized domestic R&E costs from 2022–2024 either fully in 2025 or ratably over 2025–2026.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are stated in the section; fiscal impact depends on taxpayer elections and volume of domestic R&E expenditures deducted or amortized.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Enables immediate expensing of domestic R&E, reversing the 5-year amortization requirement under current §174 for such expenditures.
- Reduces tax liability for businesses conducting domestic R&E, especially in early years of projects.
- Increases complexity in tax compliance due to bifurcation of domestic and foreign R&E treatment.
- Potentially reduces federal revenue due to accelerated deductions.
- Provides cash flow benefits to small businesses electing retroactive application.
- Requires accounting method changes under §481, generally applied on a cut-off basis without prior-year adjustments.

sections.section: SEC. 70303. MODIFICATION OF LIMITATION ON BUSINESS INTEREST.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent U.S. Business Tax Reform and Boosting Domestic Investment
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**:
   - Removes the limitation that allowed the use of EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization) instead of EBIT (earnings before interest and taxes) only for tax years beginning before January 1, 2022, under IRC §163(j)(8)(A)(v). This effectively allows EBITDA-based interest deduction calculations to continue beyond 2021.
   - Expands the definition of "floor plan financing indebtedness" under IRC §163(j)(9)(C) to include trailers and campers designed for temporary living quarters and towable or affixable to motor vehicles.

2. **Dollar Amounts**:
   - No specific dollar amounts are stated in this section.

3. **Downstream Effects**:
   - Businesses, particularly in capital-intensive industries, may deduct more interest expense due to the continued use of EBITDA rather than EBIT, potentially reducing taxable income.
   - Recreational vehicle dealers, including those selling trailers and campers, may now qualify for the floor plan financing interest deduction, increasing tax benefits for that sector.
   - Treasury is authorized to issue guidance for applying these changes to short tax years beginning after December 31, 2024, but ending before enactment.

sections.section: SEC. 70304. EXTENSION AND ENHANCEMENT OF PAID FAMILY AND MEDICAL LEAVE CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent U.S. Business Tax Reform and Boosting Domestic Investment
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Employers may now elect to calculate the paid family and medical leave (PFML) credit based on either (A) wages paid to qualifying employees on leave or (B) premiums paid for a qualifying insurance policy providing PFML.
- For option (B), the applicable percentage is determined without regard to whether any employees actually took leave during the year.
- Aggregation rules under Section 414 apply, treating related entities as a single employer, unless an entity demonstrates a substantial and legitimate business reason for not providing a written PFML policy. Acceptable reasons exclude separate lines of business, wage rates, job categories, or compliance with state/local laws, but may include grouping of employees under a common law employer.
- State or local government-mandated or -funded leave counts toward the employer’s total PFML offering but is excluded from the credit calculation.
- Eligibility for employees now includes those customarily working at least 20 hours per week and employed for at least one year (or six months, at employer election), with compensation determined on an annualized basis for part-time workers.
- Subsection 45S(i), which previously limited the credit to 2018–2019, is repealed, effectively extending the credit.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are changed or added in this section; instead, the credit continues to be based on an "applicable percentage" of wages or premiums, as defined elsewhere in the statute.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Employers gain flexibility in claiming the PFML credit, potentially increasing participation by allowing insurance-based credit claims.
- Clarification on aggregation and eligibility rules may reduce abuse and improve compliance.
- Exclusion of state-mandated benefits from the credit calculation prevents double-dipping.
- Repeal of the expiration provision and new effective date (tax years beginning after December 31, 2025) extends availability of the credit beyond prior sunset.

sections.section: SEC. 70305. EXCEPTIONS FROM LIMITATIONS ON DEDUCTION FOR BUSINESS MEALS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent U.S. Business Tax Reform and Boosting Domestic Investment
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**:
   - Amends IRC §274(o) to allow deductions for certain business meal expenses previously disallowed, specifically those described in §274(e)(8) and §274(n)(2)(C).
   - Expands §274(n)(2)(C) to exempt from the 50% meal deduction limitation meals:
     - Provided on fishing, fish processing, or fish tender vessels as defined in 46 U.S.C. §2101.
     - Provided at fish processing facilities located north of 50° N latitude in the U.S., and outside metropolitan statistical areas as defined in §143(k)(2)(B).

2. **Dollar Amounts**:
   - No specific dollar amounts are stated in the section.

3. **Downstream Effects**:
   - Increases allowable business meal deductions for commercial fishing and fish processing operations, potentially reducing taxable income for qualifying businesses.
   - May incentivize continued or expanded operations in remote fish processing locations and on vessels by reducing tax liability.
   - Effective for expenses incurred after December 31, 2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70306. INCREASED DOLLAR LIMITATIONS FOR EXPENSING OF CERTAIN DEPRECIABLE BUSINESS ASSETS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent U.S. Business Tax Reform and Boosting Domestic Investment
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Increases the Section 179 expensing limit from $1,000,000 to $2,500,000.
- Raises the phase-out threshold from $2,500,000 to $4,000,000.
- Updates the inflation adjustment base year for these amounts to calendar year 2024 (previously 2016).
- Specifies that for paragraph (5)(A), the base year remains 2017.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- Expensing limit: increased to $2,500,000.
- Phase-out threshold: increased to $4,000,000.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Allows businesses to immediately expense a greater amount of qualifying property, increasing upfront deductions.
- Expands eligibility for full expensing to larger capital investments.
- May reduce taxable income for qualifying businesses starting in tax year 2025, potentially lowering federal revenue.

sections.section: SEC. 70307. SPECIAL DEPRECIATION ALLOWANCE FOR QUALIFIED PRODUCTION PROPERTY.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent U.S. Business Tax Reform and Boosting Domestic Investment
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Creates a new 100% first-year depreciation allowance under IRC §168(n) for "qualified production property" (QPP) if the taxpayer elects.
- QPP must be nonresidential real property used in qualified production activities (manufacturing, production, or refining of tangible personal property), with original use beginning with the taxpayer, constructed between Jan 20, 2025, and Dec 31, 2028, and placed in service before Jan 1, 2031.
- Excludes office, administrative, lodging, parking, sales, research, software development, and engineering space from QPP.
- Allows certain previously used property to qualify if not used in qualified production activities from Jan 1, 2021, to May 12, 2025, and meets §179(d) acquisition rules.
- Deduction is allowed for AMT purposes without §56 adjustments.
- QPP treated as a separate property class for coordination with other depreciation rules.
- QPP excluded from alternative depreciation system (ADS) and treated as separate nonresidential real property under ADS rules.
- 10-year recapture rule applies if property use changes to non-qualified activity, triggering §1245 recapture.
- Election to claim the allowance is irrevocable without IRS consent.
- IRS directed to issue regulations defining "substantial transformation" and recapture rules for transferees.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- 100% of the adjusted basis of QPP is deductible in the year placed in service.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Accelerates depreciation deductions for qualifying real property, reducing near-term tax liabilities for manufacturers and producers.
- Encourages new construction and investment in domestic production facilities between 2025 and 2028.
- May shift taxpayer behavior toward qualifying uses and away from excluded functions (e.g., offices).
- Potential for increased audit and compliance oversight due to recapture provisions and use restrictions.
- Could reduce federal tax revenues in early years due to front-loaded deductions.

sections.section: SEC. 70308. ENHANCEMENT OF ADVANCED MANUFACTURING INVESTMENT CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent U.S. Business Tax Reform and Boosting Domestic Investment
sections.summary:
1. Policy Change: Increases the investment tax credit under Section 48D(a) from 25% to 35%.

2. Effective Date: Applies to property placed in service after December 31, 2025.

3. Downstream Effects: Increases federal tax expenditures for qualifying investments, potentially incentivizing greater private investment in eligible property starting in 2026.

sections.section: SEC. 70309. SPACEPORTS ARE TREATED LIKE AIRPORTS UNDER EXEMPT FACILITY BOND RULES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent U.S. Business Tax Reform and Boosting Domestic Investment
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes:**
   - Expands the definition of eligible private activity bonds under Section 142(a)(1) to include "spaceports" alongside airports.
   - Allows spaceport property on federally leased land to qualify as government-owned for bond eligibility, provided lease requirements are met.
   - Defines "spaceport" to include facilities for spacecraft manufacturing, repair, flight control, launch/reentry services, and crew/cargo transfer.
   - Clarifies that spaceports do not need to be open to the general public to qualify.
   - Exempts spaceport manufacturing facilities and industrial parks from the public use requirement under Section 142(c)(2)(E).
   - Exempts spaceport bonds from the federal guarantee prohibition under Section 149(b)(3) if the federal government pays rent or fees for use.

2. **Dollar Amounts:**
   - No specific dollar amounts are stated in this section.

3. **Downstream Effects:**
   - Enables tax-exempt private activity bond financing for spaceport infrastructure, potentially increasing private investment in commercial space facilities.
   - Reduces financing barriers for public-private partnerships involving spaceports on federally leased land.
   - Encourages development of space-related industrial parks and manufacturing hubs near launch/reentry sites.
   - Federal use of spaceports will not disqualify bonds from tax-exempt status, increasing attractiveness for bond investors and developers.

sections.section: SEC. 70311. MODIFICATIONS RELATED TO FOREIGN TAX CREDIT LIMITATION.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Permanent America-first International Tax Reforms
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- For purposes of calculating the foreign tax credit limitation under IRC §904(a) related to foreign source net CFC tested income:
  - Deductions under §250(a)(1)(B) and related foreign taxes under §164(a)(3) must be allocated to foreign source net CFC tested income.
  - No interest expense or R&D expenditures are to be allocated to this income.
  - Other deductions are allocable only if directly related to this income.
  - Deductions not allocable under these rules are instead allocated to U.S.-source income.
- Technical corrections to cross-references in §§904(d)(2)(H)(i), 904(d)(4)(C)(ii), and 951A(f)(1)(A).

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are stated in the section.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Increases the amount of foreign source income eligible for foreign tax credits by reducing the allocation of U.S.-based deductions (e.g., interest and R&D) to foreign income.
- Potentially increases allowable foreign tax credits for multinational corporations with CFC tested income.
- May reduce U.S. tax liability for affected taxpayers starting in tax years after December 31, 2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70312. MODIFICATIONS TO DETERMINATION OF DEEMED PAID CREDIT FOR TAXES PROPERLY ATTRIBUTABLE TO TESTED INCOME.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Permanent America-first International Tax Reforms
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Increases the deemed paid foreign tax credit under IRC §960(d)(1) from 80% to 90%.
- Modifies the gross-up calculation for deemed paid foreign tax credits to reflect the 90% rate and removes reference to subsection (b).
- Adds a new provision disallowing 10% of foreign tax credits under §901 for taxes related to distributions of previously taxed net CFC tested income excluded under §959(a) due to prior inclusion under §951A(a).

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are provided; changes are percentage-based (80% to 90% credit, 10% disallowance).

3. Downstream Effects:
- Increases allowable foreign tax credits for U.S. shareholders of CFCs, reducing effective U.S. tax on foreign income.
- Partially offsets this benefit by disallowing 10% of credits on certain distributions, limiting double benefit on previously taxed income.
- Changes effective for tax years beginning after December 31, 2025 (for credit increase) and for foreign taxes related to distributions after June 28, 2025 (for disallowance).

sections.section: SEC. 70313. SOURCING CERTAIN INCOME FROM THE SALE OF INVENTORY PRODUCED IN THE UNITED STATES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Permanent America-first International Tax Reforms
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
   - Introduces a new source rule under Section 904(b) for inventory produced in the U.S. and sold through a foreign branch.
   - If a U.S. person has a fixed place of business in a foreign country, income from the sale of U.S.-produced inventory for foreign use, and attributable to that foreign office, will be treated as foreign-source income.
   - However, only up to 50% of such income can be treated as foreign-source.

2. Dollar Amounts:
   - No specific dollar amounts are stated; the provision limits the foreign-source treatment to 50% of the relevant income.

3. Downstream Effects:
   - May increase the foreign tax credit limitation for affected taxpayers by reclassifying a portion of income as foreign-source.
   - Could reduce U.S. tax liability for multinational corporations with foreign branches selling U.S.-produced goods abroad.
   - Encourages structuring of foreign sales through foreign branches to benefit from partial foreign-source treatment.

sections.section: SEC. 70321. MODIFICATION OF DEDUCTION FOR FOREIGN-DERIVED DEDUCTION ELIGIBLE INCOME AND NET CFC TESTED INCOME.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.part: PART II--FOREIGN-DERIVED DEDUCTION ELIGIBLE INCOME AND NET CFC TESTED INCOME
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Permanent America-first International Tax Reforms
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
   - Reduces the percentage in Section 250(a)(1)(A) from 37.5% to 33.34%.
   - Reduces the percentage in Section 250(a)(1)(B) from 50% to 40%.
   - Eliminates Section 250(a)(3).

2. Dollar Amounts:
   - No specific dollar amounts stated; changes affect deduction percentages under IRC Section 250, which impacts taxable income calculations for foreign-derived intangible income (FDII) and global intangible low-taxed income (GILTI).

3. Downstream Effects:
   - Lowers the deduction available for FDII and GILTI, effectively increasing the tax liability for corporations with foreign income.
   - May reduce incentives for U.S. corporations to hold intangible assets abroad.
   - Applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70322. DETERMINATION OF DEDUCTION ELIGIBLE INCOME.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.part: PART II--FOREIGN-DERIVED DEDUCTION ELIGIBLE INCOME AND NET CFC TESTED INCOME
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Permanent America-first International Tax Reforms
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
   - Expands the definition of gross income eligible for the section 250 deduction to include income and gain from the sale or disposition (including deemed sales or transactions under section 367(d)) of:
     - Intangible property as defined in section 367(d)(4).
     - Any depreciable, amortizable, or depletable property.
   - Limits expense apportionment for purposes of section 250 to only those expenses (excluding interest and R&E expenditures) that are properly allocable to the gross income.

2. Dollar Amounts:
   - No specific dollar amounts are provided in this section.

3. Downstream Effects:
   - May increase the amount of income eligible for the FDII (Foreign-Derived Intangible Income) deduction by including gains from certain property sales.
   - Could reduce the deduction by limiting the types of expenses that can be apportioned against eligible income.
   - Effective for dispositions occurring after June 16, 2025, and for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70323. RULES RELATED TO DEEMED INTANGIBLE INCOME.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.part: PART II--FOREIGN-DERIVED DEDUCTION ELIGIBLE INCOME AND NET CFC TESTED INCOME
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Permanent America-first International Tax Reforms
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes:**
   - Replaces the term "Global Intangible Low-Taxed Income (GILTI)" with "Net CFC Tested Income" throughout the Internal Revenue Code.
   - Eliminates the tax-free deemed return on foreign investments by repealing subsections 951A(b) and 951A(d).
   - Replaces "Foreign-Derived Intangible Income (FDII)" with "Foreign-Derived Deduction Eligible Income" in Section 250 and related provisions.
   - Redesignates and restructures subsections and paragraphs in Sections 951A and 250 to reflect the above terminology changes.

2. **Dollar Amounts:**
   - No specific dollar amounts are provided in this section.

3. **Downstream Effects:**
   - Alters the tax base for U.S. shareholders of controlled foreign corporations (CFCs) by removing the deemed 10% return on qualified business asset investment (QBAI), potentially increasing taxable income.
   - Changes terminology in the FDII regime, potentially affecting eligibility and calculation of the Section 250 deduction.
   - May increase effective tax rates on foreign income due to the repeal of the deemed return exclusion.
   - Requires updates to tax compliance systems and documentation to reflect new terminology and calculation rules.
   - Effective for tax years beginning after December 31, 2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70331. EXTENSION AND MODIFICATION OF BASE EROSION MINIMUM TAX AMOUNT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Permanent America-first International Tax Reforms
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Increases the base BEAT (Base Erosion and Anti-Abuse Tax) rate from 10% to 10.5%.
- Eliminates the special higher BEAT rate previously applicable under paragraph (2).
- Renumbers affected paragraphs for consistency.
- Updates cross-references and terminology for clarity and accuracy (e.g., correcting references to securities dealers and applicable subsections).

2. Dollar Amounts:
- BEAT rate increased from 10% to 10.5%, affecting applicable multinational corporations subject to the tax.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Higher BEAT liability for affected corporations beginning in tax year 2026.
- Simplifies the BEAT rate structure by removing the tiered rate system.
- May increase federal revenue from multinational corporations due to the higher minimum tax rate on base erosion payments.

sections.section: SEC. 70341. COORDINATION OF BUSINESS INTEREST LIMITATION WITH INTEREST CAPITALIZATION PROVISIONS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Permanent America-first International Tax Reforms
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Section 163(j) is amended to clarify that the business interest expense limitation applies regardless of whether the interest is deducted or capitalized.
- Capitalized interest is now explicitly included in the scope of the Section 163(j) limitation.
- When applying the limitation, allowable interest is first applied to capitalized interest, then to deductible interest.
- Disallowed interest carried forward will not be treated as subject to capitalization provisions in future years.
- Interest capitalized under sections 263(g) (relating to interest on indebtedness incurred to carry tax-exempt obligations) and 263A(f) (relating to interest required to be capitalized for certain production expenditures) is excluded from the definition of "business interest" under Section 163(j).
- The Secretary of the Treasury is granted regulatory authority to issue guidance on the application of these rules, including coordination with Section 59A(c)(3) (Base Erosion and Anti-Abuse Tax).

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are provided in this section.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Broadens the application of the Section 163(j) limitation to include capitalized interest, potentially reducing the amount of interest that can be deducted or capitalized in a given year.
- May result in increased current tax liabilities for businesses with significant capitalized interest.
- Disallowed interest carryforwards will not be subject to capitalization in future years, potentially simplifying future tax calculations.
- Exclusion of certain capitalized interest from the definition of business interest may reduce the amount subject to limitation under Section 163(j).
- Treasury regulations may further refine application, affecting compliance and planning strategies.

sections.section: SEC. 70342. DEFINITION OF ADJUSTED TAXABLE INCOME FOR BUSINESS INTEREST LIMITATION.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Permanent America-first International Tax Reforms
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Modifies the definition of "adjusted taxable income" under IRC §163(j)(8)(A) by including amounts from Subpart F income (§951(a)), Global Intangible Low-Taxed Income (GILTI) (§951A(a)), and associated §78 gross-up.
- Corresponding deductions under §245A(a) (due to §964(e)(4)) and §250(a)(1)(B) are also included in the calculation.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are stated; impact depends on taxpayer-specific Subpart F and GILTI inclusions and related deductions.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Broadens the income base for calculating interest expense limitations under §163(j), potentially reducing allowable interest deductions for multinational corporations with significant Subpart F or GILTI income.
- May increase taxable income and effective tax liability for affected taxpayers starting in tax years beginning after December 31, 2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70351. PERMANENT EXTENSION OF LOOK-THRU RULE FOR RELATED CONTROLLED FOREIGN CORPORATIONS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Permanent America-first International Tax Reforms
sections.summary:
1. Policy Change: Removes the expiration date for the look-through rule under IRC Section 954(c)(6), which previously applied only to tax years beginning before January 1, 2026.  
2. Dollar Amounts: Not specified in this section.  
3. Downstream Effects: Allows U.S. multinational corporations to continue deferring U.S. tax on certain income (e.g., interest, rents, and royalties) received by controlled foreign corporations from related CFCs beyond 2025, potentially reducing U.S. tax liabilities and impacting federal revenue.

sections.section: SEC. 70352. REPEAL OF ELECTION FOR 1-MONTH DEFERRAL IN DETERMINATION OF TAXABLE YEAR OF SPECIFIED FOREIGN CORPORATIONS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Permanent America-first International Tax Reforms
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Eliminates Section 898(c)(2), which previously allowed specified foreign corporations (SFCs) to use a taxable year different from the required year.
- Redesignates Section 898(c)(3) as 898(c)(2), effectively removing the exception and requiring all SFCs to conform to the required year under Section 898(c)(1).
- Mandates that SFCs change their taxable year to align with the required year starting after November 30, 2025.
- Treats the taxable year change as taxpayer-initiated and automatically approved by the Secretary of the Treasury.
- Requires the Secretary to issue regulations or guidance on allocation of foreign taxes across the transition year and the succeeding year.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are stated in this section.

3. Downstream Effects:
- SFCs must align their taxable year with the U.S. shareholder’s year, potentially increasing compliance costs.
- May affect timing of income inclusion under Subpart F and GILTI rules.
- Could alter timing of foreign tax credit claims due to required allocation of foreign taxes across adjusted taxable years.
- Treasury guidance will be necessary to manage transitional foreign tax allocation and prevent double taxation or mismatches.

sections.section: SEC. 70353. RESTORATION OF LIMITATION ON DOWNWARD ATTRIBUTION OF STOCK OWNERSHIP IN APPLYING CONSTRUCTIVE OWNERSHIP RULES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Permanent America-first International Tax Reforms
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Section 958(b) is amended to prevent attribution of stock ownership from non-U.S. persons to U.S. persons under Section 318(a)(3)(A)-(C), limiting indirect ownership rules.
- A new Section 951B is added to Subpart F, creating a parallel regime for “foreign controlled United States shareholders” (FCUS shareholders) of “foreign controlled foreign corporations” (FCFCs).
- FCUS shareholders are defined as U.S. persons who would be U.S. shareholders if the ownership threshold were more than 50% instead of 10%, and without applying the new limitation in 958(b)(4).
- FCFCs are foreign corporations that would be CFCs if FCUS shareholders were treated as U.S. shareholders and the modified attribution rules applied.
- Section 951B applies Subpart F and Section 951A (GILTI) to FCUS shareholders and FCFCs using modified definitions.
- Treasury is authorized to issue regulations to extend these definitions to other parts of the Code, including information reporting and PFIC coordination.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are stated; revenue impact would depend on the volume of income inclusions under the new FCUS/FCFC regime.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Expands Subpart F and GILTI inclusion rules to U.S. persons with controlling interests in foreign corporations not currently classified as CFCs.
- Limits the ability of foreign-parented multinational groups to avoid Subpart F and GILTI rules through ownership structuring.
- Increases compliance and reporting obligations for affected U.S. shareholders.
- Effective for tax years of foreign corporations beginning after December 31, 2025.
- May increase tax revenue by broadening the base of foreign earnings subject to U.S. taxation.

sections.section: SEC. 70354. MODIFICATIONS TO PRO RATA SHARE RULES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 3--ESTABLISHING CERTAINTY AND COMPETITIVENESS FOR AMERICAN JOB CREATORS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Permanent America-first International Tax Reforms
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Revises IRC §951(a) to require U.S. shareholders of a controlled foreign corporation (CFC) to include in gross income their pro rata share of the CFC’s subpart F income for any day they own stock during the CFC year, not just at year-end.
- Requires inclusion of IRC §956 amounts only for shareholders owning stock on the last day the entity is a CFC during the CFC year.
- Defines the pro rata share of subpart F income based on ownership during the period when the shareholder is a U.S. shareholder and the entity is a CFC.
- Specifies that income inclusion occurs in the shareholder’s tax year that includes the last day of stock ownership during the CFC year.
- Grants Treasury authority to issue regulations, including rules for closing the CFC’s tax year upon stock disposition.
- Amends §951A(b) and §951A(c) to align tested income and pro rata share determinations with the revised §951(a)(3) timing rules.
- Modifies the pro rata share determination under §951A to apply to any day in the CFC’s tax year, not just the last day it is a CFC.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are stated in the section.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Expands the scope of subpart F income inclusion by requiring income recognition for any day of stock ownership during the CFC year, potentially increasing U.S. shareholder tax liability.
- May accelerate or increase income inclusion for shareholders who acquire or dispose of CFC stock mid-year.
- Aligns timing and measurement of tested income and subpart F income, simplifying coordination between §951 and §951A.
- Treasury may impose mandatory year-end closings for CFCs upon stock transfers, affecting compliance and reporting.
- Transition rule prevents certain dividends paid before or during the transition period from being treated as subpart F income, avoiding double inclusion or unintended tax consequences. Applies to dividends paid before June 28, 2025, or between June 28, 2025, and the first CFC tax year beginning after December 31, 2025, under specified conditions.

sections.section: SEC. 70401. ENHANCEMENT OF EMPLOYER-PROVIDED CHILD CARE CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent Investments in Families and Children
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Increases the percentage of qualified child care expenditures eligible for the credit from 25% to 40%, and to 50% for eligible small businesses.
- Raises the annual maximum credit from $150,000 to $500,000 ($600,000 for eligible small businesses).
- Defines "eligible small business" as one meeting the gross receipts test under section 448(c), modified to use a 5-year lookback period instead of 3 years.
- Expands eligibility to include child care services provided through contracts with third-party intermediaries.
- Allows jointly owned or operated child care facilities to qualify for the credit.
- Directs the Secretary to issue regulations and guidance to implement the changes, including for intermediary and joint facility provisions.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- Credit rate: 40% of qualified expenditures (50% for eligible small businesses).
- Annual credit cap: $500,000 ($600,000 for eligible small businesses).
- Caps indexed for inflation starting in tax year 2027, using 2025 as the base year.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Increases potential tax credit value for businesses investing in child care services.
- Expands access to the credit for smaller businesses and those using third-party providers.
- Encourages joint ventures in child care facility operations without losing credit eligibility.
- May increase employer-sponsored child care availability due to enhanced financial incentives.

sections.section: SEC. 70402. ENHANCEMENT OF ADOPTION CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent Investments in Families and Children
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**:
   - A new refundable portion of the adoption tax credit is created: up to $5,000 of the credit under Section 23(a)(1) will now be treated as refundable (i.e., treated under subpart C rather than subpart A).
   - Inflation adjustments are extended to the refundable portion of the credit starting in tax year 2025, using calendar year 2024 as the base year.
   - The carryforward provision in Section 23(c)(1) is modified to exclude the refundable portion of the credit from being carried forward.

2. **Dollar Amounts**:
   - Up to $5,000 of the adoption tax credit is now refundable.
   - All relevant dollar thresholds in Section 23(a)(3), (a)(4), (b)(1), and (b)(2)(A)(i) will be adjusted annually for inflation.

3. **Downstream Effects**:
   - Taxpayers with lower tax liability may now benefit from up to $5,000 of the adoption credit even if they owe no taxes, increasing accessibility for low-income families.
   - Future values of the credit and income thresholds will increase with inflation, preserving real value over time.
   - The non-refundable portion of the credit remains subject to carryforward rules, while the refundable portion must be used in the year claimed.

sections.section: SEC. 70403. RECOGNIZING INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS FOR PURPOSES OF DETERMINING WHETHER A CHILD HAS SPECIAL NEEDS FOR PURPOSES OF THE ADOPTION CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent Investments in Families and Children
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes: Expands eligibility in Section 23(d)(3) to include Indian tribal governments alongside States for purposes outlined in subparagraphs (A) and (B).

2. Dollar Amounts: Not specified in this section.

3. Downstream Effects: Indian tribal governments will now be eligible for the same tax-related provisions or benefits previously limited to States under Section 23(d)(3), effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2024.

sections.section: SEC. 70404. ENHANCEMENT OF THE DEPENDENT CARE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent Investments in Families and Children
sections.summary:
1. Policy Change: Increases the maximum exclusion for employer-provided dependent care assistance from $5,000 to $7,500 for individuals, and from $2,500 to $3,750 for married individuals filing separately.

2. Dollar Amounts: Increase of $2,500 for individuals and $1,250 for married individuals filing separately.

3. Downstream Effects: Higher tax-free benefit limits may incentivize greater employer participation in dependent care assistance programs and provide increased tax savings for employees; potential reduction in federal income tax revenue beginning in tax year 2026.

sections.section: SEC. 70405. ENHANCEMENT OF CHILD AND DEPENDENT CARE TAX CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent Investments in Families and Children
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**:  
   - Revises the "applicable percentage" used in calculating the Child and Dependent Care Tax Credit (CDCTC).
   - Sets the base applicable percentage at 50%.
   - Reduces the percentage by 1 point for each $2,000 (or fraction thereof) of adjusted gross income (AGI) over $15,000, but not below 35%.
   - Further reduces the percentage by 1 point for each $2,000 ($4,000 for joint filers) of AGI over $75,000 ($150,000 for joint filers), but not below 20%.

2. **Dollar Amounts**:  
   - Phase-down thresholds: $15,000 initial reduction threshold; $75,000/$150,000 secondary reduction thresholds.
   - Minimum applicable percentage: 20%.

3. **Downstream Effects**:  
   - Expands eligibility for higher CDCTC rates to more middle-income taxpayers by raising the AGI thresholds for phase-downs.
   - Increases tax credit amounts for qualifying taxpayers with AGI between $15,000 and $150,000 (joint), potentially reducing net tax liability and increasing refunds.
   - May increase federal outlays or reduce revenue due to higher average credit amounts claimed.

sections.section: SEC. 70411. TAX CREDIT FOR CONTRIBUTIONS OF INDIVIDUALS TO SCHOLARSHIP GRANTING ORGANIZATIONS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent Investments in Families and Children
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Creates a new federal individual income tax credit (Section 25F) for cash contributions to scholarship granting organizations (SGOs) that fund K–12 education scholarships for eligible students.
- Credit is non-refundable and subject to a $1,700 annual cap per taxpayer.
- Credit is reduced by any state-level tax credits received for the same contributions.
- Contributions qualifying for the federal credit cannot also be claimed as charitable deductions under Section 170.
- Unused credit amounts may be carried forward for up to five years.
- Defines eligible students as those from households with income ≤300% of area median gross income and eligible to enroll in public K–12 schools.
- SGOs must be 501(c)(3) organizations (not private foundations), maintain separate accounts for qualified contributions, and meet specific operational requirements (e.g., 90% of income used for scholarships, no earmarking for specific students, income verification).
- SGOs must prioritize renewing scholarships and siblings of current recipients.
- SGOs cannot award scholarships to disqualified persons (per rules similar to Section 4946).
- States must voluntarily opt in and submit annual certified lists of qualifying SGOs to the IRS.
- Adds new Section 139K to exclude from gross income any scholarships received from SGOs for qualified K–12 education expenses.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- Maximum federal tax credit per individual: $1,700 annually.
- SGOs must allocate at least 90% of income to scholarships.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Encourages increased private donations to SGOs by offering a federal tax credit.
- May reduce federal tax revenues due to new credit.
- Could increase access to private K–12 education for low- and moderate-income families.
- States must establish administrative processes to certify and report eligible SGOs.
- Potential shift in education funding dynamics, with more private funds supporting K–12 education.

sections.section: SEC. 70412. EXCLUSION FOR EMPLOYER PAYMENTS OF STUDENT LOANS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent Investments in Families and Children
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Removes the expiration date (January 1, 2026) for employer-provided educational assistance under Section 127(c)(1)(B), making the provision permanent.
- Introduces a new inflation adjustment mechanism for the $5,250 annual exclusion limit on educational assistance benefits under Section 127(a)(2), effective for taxable years beginning after 2026.
- Adjustments will be based on the cost-of-living adjustment under Section 1(f)(3), using calendar year 2025 as the base year.
- Increases will be rounded to the nearest $50.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- The current $5,250 annual exclusion limit for educational assistance benefits will be subject to inflation adjustments starting in 2027.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Permanently extends tax-free treatment of employer-provided educational assistance, including student loan repayment benefits.
- Beginning in 2027, the $5,250 cap will increase with inflation, potentially expanding tax-free benefits for employees and increasing employer participation.
- May lead to higher federal revenue loss over time due to the inflation-adjusted cap.

sections.section: SEC. 70413. ADDITIONAL EXPENSES TREATED AS QUALIFIED HIGHER EDUCATION EXPENSES FOR PURPOSES OF 529 ACCOUNTS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent Investments in Families and Children
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
   - Expands the definition of "qualified higher education expense" under Section 529(c)(7) to include a broader range of K-12 expenses:
     - Tuition at public, private, or religious elementary and secondary schools.
     - Curriculum and curricular materials.
     - Books and instructional materials.
     - Online educational materials.
     - Tuition for tutoring or educational classes (with qualifications for instructors).
     - Fees for standardized tests, AP exams, and college admission exams.
     - Fees for dual enrollment in higher education institutions.
     - Educational therapies for students with disabilities provided by licensed/accredited practitioners.

2. Dollar Amounts:
   - Increases the annual limit on 529 plan distributions for K-12 expenses from $10,000 to $20,000.

3. Downstream Effects:
   - Expands allowable uses of 529 plan funds, potentially increasing withdrawals for K-12 education.
   - May incentivize higher contributions to 529 plans due to broader expense eligibility and increased annual withdrawal cap.
   - Could reduce out-of-pocket K-12 education costs for families using 529 plans.
   - Effective for distributions made after enactment for expanded uses; increased limit effective for tax years beginning after December 31, 2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70414. CERTAIN POSTSECONDARY CREDENTIALING EXPENSES TREATED AS QUALIFIED HIGHER EDUCATION EXPENSES FOR PURPOSES OF 529 ACCOUNTS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent Investments in Families and Children
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Expands the definition of "qualified higher education expenses" under Section 529 to include "qualified postsecondary credentialing expenses."
- Defines "qualified postsecondary credentialing expenses" to include:
  - Tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment for recognized postsecondary credential programs.
  - Testing fees required to obtain or maintain a recognized postsecondary credential.
  - Continuing education fees required to maintain such credentials.
- Defines "recognized postsecondary credential program" as one that:
  - Appears on a state list under the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA).
  - Is listed in the Veterans Benefits Administration’s WEAMS directory.
  - Is recognized by a credentialing organization as preparatory for a qualifying exam.
  - Is identified by the Secretary of the Treasury in consultation with the Secretary of Labor.
- Defines "recognized postsecondary credential" to include:
  - Industry-recognized credentials from accredited programs or those listed in the DoD COOL directory.
  - Registered apprenticeship certificates.
  - State or federally issued occupational/professional licenses and related certifications.
  - Credentials defined under WIOA section 3(52) from qualifying programs.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are stated; the section expands allowable uses of 529 plan funds.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Increases the range of educational and workforce training expenses eligible for tax-advantaged 529 plan distributions.
- May incentivize use of 529 plans for non-traditional education paths, including vocational training, apprenticeships, and professional licensing.
- Could lead to increased demand for credentialing programs recognized under the specified criteria.

sections.section: SEC. 70415. MODIFICATION OF EXCISE TAX ON INVESTMENT INCOME OF CERTAIN PRIVATE COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent Investments in Families and Children
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Revises Section 4968 to impose a tiered excise tax on net investment income of private colleges and universities based on their "student adjusted endowment."
- Defines "applicable educational institution" as one with at least 3,000 tuition-paying students, over 50% of whom are in the U.S., and a student adjusted endowment of at least $500,000, excluding state colleges/universities.
- Redefines "student adjusted endowment" as total non-exempt-purpose assets divided by the number of students (measured as full-time equivalent).
- Expands "net investment income" to include:
  - Interest from student loans made by the institution or related organizations.
  - Federally-subsidized royalty income, even if previously exempt under regulatory rules.
- Requires inclusion of assets and net investment income from related organizations, unless not controlled by or designated for the institution.
- Mandates reporting of tuition-paying student counts and total student counts on annual tax filings (Form 990) for applicable institutions.
- Authorizes Treasury to issue anti-avoidance regulations, including rules on restructuring endowments.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- Excise tax rates based on student adjusted endowment:
  - 1.4% for $500,000–$750,000 per student.
  - 4% for $750,000–$2,000,000 per student.
  - 8% for over $2,000,000 per student.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Increases tax liability for high-endowment private institutions, especially those with large per-student endowments.
- Expands taxable income base by including student loan interest and certain royalty income.
- Increases compliance burden through new reporting requirements and inclusion of related organizations’ assets/income.
- May incentivize institutions to restructure endowments or related entities to minimize tax exposure, subject to new anti-avoidance rules.
- Effective for tax years beginning after December 31, 2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70416. EXPANDING APPLICATION OF TAX ON EXCESS COMPENSATION WITHIN TAX-EXEMPT ORGANIZATIONS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Permanent Investments in Families and Children
sections.summary:
1. Policy Change: Redefines "covered employee" under Section 4960(c)(2) to include both current and former employees of applicable tax-exempt organizations (or their predecessors) who were employed in any taxable year beginning after December 31, 2016.

2. Dollar Amounts: None specified.

3. Downstream Effects: Expands the pool of individuals subject to the excise tax on excess compensation and parachute payments under Section 4960, potentially increasing tax liability for applicable tax-exempt organizations starting in taxable years after December 31, 2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70421. PERMANENT RENEWAL AND ENHANCEMENT OF OPPORTUNITY ZONES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Permanent Investments in Community Development
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Opportunity Zone (OZ) designations will now be re-evaluated every 10 years starting July 1, 2026 ("decennial determination date").
- The special rule allowing Puerto Rico to designate all low-income tracts as OZs is repealed effective December 31, 2026.
- OZ designation limits now apply per determination period, not cumulatively.
- The definition of "low-income community" is revised to include tracts with poverty rates ≥20% and median family income ≤125% of state/metropolitan median.
- The rule allowing contiguous tracts to qualify as OZs is repealed.
- OZ designations will last 10 years from the January 1 following certification.
- The sunset on OZ gain deferral elections is repealed; elections are now disallowed only if a prior election is in effect.
- Gain deferral ends at the earlier of sale or 5 years after investment.
- Basis increases by 10% (30% for rural funds) for investments held ≥5 years.
- Rural OZs are defined as areas outside cities >50,000 or adjacent urbanized areas.
- For investments held ≥10 years, basis equals fair market value at sale or at 30 years.
- OZ property acquisition dates are updated to align with new designation periods.
- Rural OZs require only 50% substantial improvement threshold (vs. 100% standard).
- New annual reporting requirements for OZ and rural OZ funds and businesses, including asset values, employment data, property details, and investor transactions.
- Penalties for noncompliance: $500/day up to $10,000 ($50,000 for large funds); intentional disregard increases penalties up to $2,500/day and $250,000 cap.
- Mandatory electronic filing for OZ fund reports.
- Treasury must publish annual reports on OZ fund activity, including investment amounts, employment impacts, and tract-level outcomes.
- Starting in year 6, reports must include economic impact metrics (e.g., job creation, poverty rates, housing data).
- Separate reporting required for rural OZ funds.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- $15 million appropriated to IRS through FY2028 for reporting implementation.
- Penalties: $500/day up to $10,000 per return; $2,500/day and $250,000 cap for intentional disregard; inflation-adjusted annually after 2025.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Regular re-evaluation of OZ designations may shift investment patterns.
- Stricter eligibility criteria and repeal of contiguous tract rule may reduce number of qualifying OZs.
- Shorter deferral period (5 years) may reduce long-term capital lock-in.
- Enhanced basis step-up for rural investments incentivizes rural OZ participation.
- Expanded reporting and penalties increase compliance burden on funds and businesses.
- Treasury reporting may inform future legislative or regulatory changes based on economic outcomes.
- Increased transparency may affect investor behavior and public scrutiny of OZ program effectiveness.

sections.section: SEC. 70422. PERMANENT ENHANCEMENT OF LOW-INCOME HOUSING TAX CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Permanent Investments in Community Development
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
   - Permanently increases the state housing credit ceiling for the Low-Income Housing Tax Credit (LIHTC) starting in calendar years after 2025.
   - Adjusts the per capita credit allocation multiplier from 1.125 to 1.12.
   - Modifies the tax-exempt bond financing requirement for LIHTC eligibility:
     - Previously, 50% or more of a building's aggregate basis had to be financed with tax-exempt bonds.
     - New rule allows eligibility if either:
       - 50% or more of the basis is financed with tax-exempt bonds, or
       - At least 25% is financed with such bonds, and those bonds (issued after 12/31/2025) finance at least 5% of the building's aggregate basis.

2. Dollar Amounts:
   - Per capita multiplier for state housing credit ceiling set at 1.12 (from 1.125), affecting annual LIHTC allocations.

3. Downstream Effects:
   - Expands access to LIHTC by easing bond financing thresholds, potentially increasing the number of qualifying affordable housing projects.
   - May lead to increased demand for tax-exempt bonds post-2025.
   - Could result in higher overall LIHTC allocations to states due to permanent ceiling increase.

sections.section: SEC. 70423. PERMANENT EXTENSION OF NEW MARKETS TAX CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Permanent Investments in Community Development
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
   - The annual New Markets Tax Credit (NMTC) allocation authority under Section 45D(f)(1)(H) is extended indefinitely beyond 2025 by replacing the fixed range "2020 through 2025" with "each calendar year after 2019".
   - Modifies the carryover rules under Section 45D(f)(3):
     - Introduces a five-year limit on the carryforward of unused NMTC allocation authority.
     - Deems all unused allocation from years before 2026 as having occurred in 2025 for purposes of the five-year carryforward limit.

2. Dollar Amounts:
   - No specific dollar amounts are changed or introduced in this section; changes pertain to the duration and carryforward treatment of existing NMTC allocation authority.

3. Downstream Effects:
   - Makes the NMTC program permanent beyond 2025, allowing continued annual allocations without further legislative renewal.
   - Limits the time window for using unused NMTC allocations to five years, potentially accelerating deployment of credits and reducing long-term backlog.
   - Reclassifies pre-2026 unused allocations as 2025 excess, effectively starting the five-year countdown in 2025 for all prior unused amounts.

sections.section: SEC. 70424. PERMANENT AND EXPANDED REINSTATEMENT OF PARTIAL DEDUCTION FOR CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS OF INDIVIDUALS WHO DO NOT ELECT TO ITEMIZE.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Permanent Investments in Community Development
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes: Increases the above-the-line charitable contribution deduction limit under IRC Section 170(p) from $300 ($600 for joint filers) to $1,000 ($2,000 for joint filers). Removes the limitation that applied only to tax years beginning in 2021.

2. Dollar Amounts: Deduction cap increased to $1,000 for individuals and $2,000 for joint filers.

3. Downstream Effects: Expands eligibility for non-itemizers to deduct higher charitable contributions starting in tax year 2026, potentially increasing charitable giving and reducing taxable income for more filers, resulting in decreased federal revenue.

sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Permanent Investments in Community Development
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Introduces a new 0.5% floor on the deductibility of charitable contributions by individuals under IRC §170(b)(1)(I). Only contributions exceeding 0.5% of the taxpayer’s contribution base are deductible.
- Establishes a priority order for applying the 0.5% floor across different types of charitable contributions (subparagraphs D, C, B, E, A, G).
- Modifies carryforward rules under §170(d)(1) to allow disallowed contributions due to the 0.5% floor to be carried forward only from years in which the floor was exceeded.
- Updates coordination rules to reflect the new 0.5% floor in relation to the non-itemizer deduction (§170(p)).
- Revises §170(b)(1)(G)(i) to clarify that the 60% AGI limit for cash contributions is reduced by the amount of other contributions under subparagraph (A).
- Updates coordination provisions in §170(b)(1)(G)(iii) and §170(b)(1)(B) to reflect interaction between subparagraphs (A) and (G).

2. Dollar Amounts:
- 0.5% of the taxpayer’s contribution base is the new minimum threshold for deductibility of charitable contributions.
- Cash contributions remain deductible up to 60% of AGI, but now reduced by other contributions under subparagraph (A).

3. Downstream Effects:
- Reduces the number of taxpayers eligible to deduct small charitable contributions.
- May reduce total itemized deductions and increase taxable income for lower-contributing taxpayers.
- Increases complexity in calculating allowable deductions and carryforwards.
- Could impact charitable giving behavior, particularly among taxpayers with lower contribution levels.
- Applies to tax years beginning after December 31, 2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70426. 1-PERCENT FLOOR ON DEDUCTION OF CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS MADE BY CORPORATIONS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Permanent Investments in Community Development
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Revises the corporate charitable contribution deduction limit under IRC §170(b)(2)(A): deductions are now only allowed for contributions exceeding 1% of taxable income and capped at 10% of taxable income.
- Modifies carryforward rules under §170(d)(2):
  - Contributions disallowed due to the 10% cap can be carried forward for up to 5 years.
  - Contributions disallowed due to the new 1% floor can only be carried forward if the 10% cap was exceeded in the original year.
  - Carryforwards are applied on a FIFO basis.
  - Carryforwards are reduced if they would increase a net operating loss (NOL) carryover under §172.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- Deduction floor: 1% of taxable income.
- Deduction ceiling: 10% of taxable income.
- Carryforward limit: 5 years.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Reduces immediate deductibility of corporate charitable contributions by introducing a 1% floor.
- May discourage smaller charitable contributions from corporations.
- Increases complexity in tax planning due to interaction with NOL provisions and conditional carryforward eligibility.
- Potentially delays tax benefits for charitable giving, affecting corporate cash flow and charitable organizations’ funding.

sections.section: SEC. 70427. PERMANENT INCREASE IN LIMITATION ON COVER OVER OF TAX ON DISTILLED SPIRITS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Permanent Investments in Community Development
sections.summary:
1. Policy Change: Amends 26 U.S.C. § 7652(f)(1) to set the rate at "$13.25, or" (likely referencing a specific excise tax rate for imported distilled spirits, aligning it with domestic rates).

2. Dollar Amount: $13.25 per proof gallon.

3. Downstream Effects: Harmonizes the excise tax rate on imported distilled spirits with domestic rates starting January 1, 2026, potentially affecting importers' tax liabilities and federal excise tax revenue.

sections.section: SEC. 70428. NONPROFIT COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES IN REMOTE NATIVE VILLAGES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Permanent Investments in Community Development
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Activities related to participation or investment in Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands fisheries (e.g., harvesting, processing, transportation, sales, marketing) by entities listed in Section 305(i)(1)(D) of the Magnuson-Stevens Act are deemed substantially related to their tax-exempt purpose under IRC §501(a), provided they further the purposes in Section 305(i)(1)(A).
- Transfers of assets from wholly owned subsidiaries engaged in such fisheries activities to their parent entities (as defined above) within 18 months of enactment are non-taxable events. Income from such transferred activities remains tax-exempt.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are stated.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Ensures continued tax-exempt status for certain fisheries-related activities by qualifying them as mission-related.
- Allows tax-free restructuring or consolidation of fisheries-related operations within qualifying entities.
- May incentivize internal asset transfers and operational realignments within community development quota (CDQ) groups to optimize tax treatment.

sections.section: SEC. 70429. ADJUSTMENT OF CHARITABLE DEDUCTION FOR CERTAIN EXPENSES INCURRED IN SUPPORT OF NATIVE ALASKAN SUBSISTENCE WHALING.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Permanent Investments in Community Development
sections.summary:
1. Policy Change: Increases the cap on the charitable deduction for certain contributions made by non-itemizers under IRC §170(n)(1) from $10,000 to $50,000.

2. Dollar Amounts: Raises the maximum allowable deduction by $40,000.

3. Downstream Effects: Expands tax benefits for higher-value charitable contributions by non-itemizing taxpayers, potentially increasing charitable giving and reducing federal tax revenue beginning in tax year 2026.

sections.section: SEC. 70430. EXCEPTION TO PERCENTAGE OF COMPLETION METHOD OF ACCOUNTING FOR CERTAIN RESIDENTIAL CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Permanent Investments in Community Development
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**:
   - Replaces the term "home construction contract" with "residential construction contract" throughout Section 460(e).
   - Expands the eligibility for the percentage-of-completion method exception by allowing a 3-year average gross receipts test (instead of 2-year) for residential construction contracts that are not home construction contracts.
   - Eliminates paragraph (4) and renumbers paragraph (5) as paragraph (4); updates internal cross-references accordingly.
   - Applies the exception from the percentage-of-completion method under the Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) to "residential construction contracts" instead of only "home construction contracts".

2. **Dollar Amounts**:
   - No specific dollar amounts are stated in this section.

3. **Downstream Effects**:
   - Broadens the scope of construction contracts eligible for more favorable tax treatment under the percentage-of-completion method exception.
   - Potentially reduces taxable income for contractors engaged in broader categories of residential construction, including under AMT rules.
   - May result in deferred tax liabilities for qualifying contractors due to delayed income recognition.

sections.section: SEC. 70431. EXPANSION OF QUALIFIED SMALL BUSINESS STOCK GAIN EXCLUSION.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter D--Permanent Investments in Small Business and Rural America
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Section 1202(a)(1) is revised to phase in capital gains exclusions for qualified small business stock (QSBS) based on acquisition date and holding period.
- QSBS acquired after the enactment date qualifies for exclusion if held at least 3 years; stock acquired before or on the enactment date must be held over 5 years.
- Applicable exclusion percentages are: 50% for 3 years, 75% for 4 years, and 100% for 5 or more years.
- The $10 million per-issuer gain exclusion cap is increased to $15 million for QSBS acquired after the enactment date.
- The $50 million gross asset limit for QSBS eligibility is increased to $75 million.
- Inflation adjustments are added for both the $15 million per-issuer limit (starting in 2027) and the $75 million gross asset threshold (also starting in 2027).
- Married individuals filing separately have per-issuer limits halved ($5M or half of $15M).
- Stock acquired before the Creating Small Business Jobs Act of 2010 retains exemption from AMT preference item treatment; this treatment is not extended to post-enactment stock.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- New per-issuer gain exclusion cap: $15,000,000 (up from $10,000,000) for post-enactment stock.
- Gross asset limit for QSBS eligibility: increased from $50,000,000 to $75,000,000.
- Inflation adjustments apply to both the $15M and $75M thresholds beginning in tax years after 2026.
- Married filing separately: per-issuer exclusion caps are $5,000,000 (pre-enactment stock) and half of the inflation-adjusted $15,000,000 (post-enactment stock).

3. Downstream Effects:
- Incentivizes earlier investment in small businesses by offering phased capital gains exclusions.
- Expands access to QSBS benefits by raising asset thresholds and per-issuer limits.
- May increase taxpayer planning complexity due to phased exclusion rates and dual holding period rules.
- Potential revenue loss due to higher exclusion limits and broader eligibility.
- Inflation indexing preserves real value of exclusion thresholds over time.

sections.section: SEC. 70432. REPEAL OF REVISION TO DE MINIMIS RULES FOR THIRD PARTY NETWORK TRANSACTIONS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter D--Permanent Investments in Small Business and Rural America
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
   - Reinstates the pre-American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) de minimis reporting threshold for third-party settlement organizations (TPSOs) under IRC §6050W(e): reporting is required only if a payee has over $20,000 in aggregate payments and more than 200 transactions in a calendar year.
   - Applies the same de minimis thresholds to determine whether payments are subject to backup withholding under IRC §3406(b)(8).
   - Adds an exception: if a payee had reportable transactions in the prior year, all payments in the current year are treated as reportable, regardless of whether thresholds are met.

2. Dollar Amounts:
   - Reporting threshold reinstated to over $20,000 in payments and more than 200 transactions per year.

3. Downstream Effects:
   - Reduces the number of TPSO transactions subject to IRS reporting and backup withholding compared to the ARPA standard ($600 threshold with no transaction minimum).
   - Likely decreases administrative burden for TPSOs and reduces the volume of 1099-K forms issued.
   - May reduce IRS visibility into lower-volume gig economy and peer-to-peer transactions.

sections.section: SEC. 70433. INCREASE IN THRESHOLD FOR REQUIRING INFORMATION REPORTING WITH RESPECT TO CERTAIN PAYEES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter D--Permanent Investments in Small Business and Rural America
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**:
   - Raises the Form 1099 reporting threshold under IRC §6041(a) from $600 to $2,000.
   - Adds an annual inflation adjustment to the threshold starting in calendar year 2027, using the cost-of-living adjustment formula in IRC §1(f)(3), with 2025 as the base year.
   - Applies the new threshold to remuneration reporting under IRC §6041A(a)(2).
   - Applies the new threshold to backup withholding rules under IRC §3406(b)(6).
   - Updates statutory language to reflect the new threshold and changes “taxable year” to “calendar year” for consistency.

2. **Dollar Amounts**:
   - Increases the reporting threshold from $600 to $2,000.
   - Future threshold increases will be rounded to the nearest $100.

3. **Downstream Effects**:
   - Reduces the number of Form 1099s required to be filed by payors for small-dollar payments.
   - Reduces administrative burden for small businesses and gig economy participants.
   - May reduce the volume of information returns received by the IRS, potentially impacting tax compliance monitoring.
   - Alters the scope of backup withholding obligations, potentially reducing withholding on lower-dollar payments.

sections.section: SEC. 70434. TREATMENT OF CERTAIN QUALIFIED SOUND RECORDING PRODUCTIONS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter D--Permanent Investments in Small Business and Rural America
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes:**
