   - Expands Section 181 to include "qualified sound recording production" alongside film, television, and live theatrical productions.
   - Defines "qualified sound recording production" as a sound recording (per 17 U.S.C. §101) produced and recorded in the U.S.
   - Allows immediate expensing under Section 181 for qualified sound recording productions, subject to a cap.
   - Prohibits other deductions or amortization for qualified sound recording productions if expensing is elected.
   - Applies Section 181 termination provisions to sound recording productions.
   - Includes qualified sound recording productions as eligible property for 100% bonus depreciation under Section 168(k).
   - Specifies that qualified sound recording productions are considered placed in service at initial release or broadcast.

2. **Dollar Amounts:**
   - Caps expensing under Section 181 for qualified sound recording productions at $150,000 per production or in aggregate per taxable year.

3. **Downstream Effects:**
   - Enables music producers and recording companies to immediately expense up to $150,000 of production costs per year, improving cash flow and potentially incentivizing more domestic production.
   - Aligns tax treatment of sound recordings with that of films and live theatrical productions.
   - Allows accelerated cost recovery via bonus depreciation for qualifying sound recording productions, further reducing taxable income in the year of release.

sections.section: SEC. 70435. EXCLUSION OF INTEREST ON LOANS SECURED BY RURAL OR AGRICULTURAL REAL PROPERTY.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter D--Permanent Investments in Small Business and Rural America
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- New IRC Section 139L excludes 25% of interest income from gross income for qualified lenders on qualified real estate loans.
- Defines "qualified lender" to include FDIC-insured banks, regulated insurance companies, U.S.-based banking or insurance holding company subsidiaries, and certain federally chartered farm credit institutions.
- Defines "qualified real estate loan" as loans secured by rural or agricultural real estate or leasehold mortgages thereon, made to non-foreign entities, and originated after enactment (excluding refinancings of pre-enactment loans).
- Defines "rural or agricultural real estate" to include land used for agriculture, fishing, seafood processing, or aquaculture, excluding non-U.S. property.
- Section 265 coordination: modifies tax-exempt interest disallowance rules to reflect the 25% exclusion, adjusting treatment of indebtedness and basis calculations accordingly.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- 25% of interest income on qualifying loans is excluded from gross income for tax purposes.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Reduces taxable income for qualifying lenders, effectively lowering their tax liability on eligible loan interest.
- Encourages lending to rural and agricultural sectors by increasing after-tax returns on such loans.
- Potentially increases capital availability for rural and agricultural borrowers.
- May reduce federal tax revenue due to the partial exclusion of interest income.

sections.section: SEC. 70436. REDUCTION OF TRANSFER AND MANUFACTURING TAXES FOR CERTAIN DEVICES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter D--Permanent Investments in Small Business and Rural America
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Reduces the transfer and making tax under the National Firearms Act (NFA) to $0 for firearms that are not machineguns or destructive devices.
- Maintains the $200 tax for transfers and making of machineguns and destructive devices.
- Clarifies in Section 4182(a) that firearms exempted under the new $0 tax provision are treated as if the tax has been paid for excise tax exemption purposes.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- $200 tax remains for machineguns and destructive devices.
- $0 tax for all other NFA firearms (e.g., short-barreled rifles, short-barreled shotguns, suppressors).

3. Downstream Effects:
- Eliminates federal tax burden for most NFA-regulated firearms except machineguns and destructive devices.
- Likely increases demand and legal transfers of suppressors and short-barreled firearms due to removal of $200 tax.
- Reduces federal revenue from NFA transfer and making taxes.
- Simplifies compliance and administration for non-machinegun NFA items.

sections.section: SEC. 70437. TREATMENT OF CAPITAL GAINS FROM THE SALE OF CERTAIN FARMLAND PROPERTY.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter D--Permanent Investments in Small Business and Rural America
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Establishes a new Section 1062 of the Internal Revenue Code allowing taxpayers to elect installment payment of capital gains tax from the sale or exchange of "qualified farmland property" to "qualified farmers."
- Taxpayers may pay the applicable net tax liability in four equal annual installments.
- Defines "qualified farmland property" as U.S. real property used or leased for farming for most of the prior 10 years and subject to a 10-year post-sale farming-use covenant.
- Defines "qualified farmer" as an individual actively engaged in farming per the Food Security Act of 1986.
- Election must be made by the tax return due date for the year of the sale.
- For partnerships and S corporations, the election is made at the partner/shareholder level.
- Installment acceleration occurs upon late payment, death (for individuals), or liquidation/cessation of business (for C corporations, trusts, estates), unless the buyer assumes liability for remaining payments.
- Deficiencies are prorated across installments unless due to negligence or fraud.
- Taxpayers must submit the farming-use covenant with their tax return.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are stated; the installment applies to the "applicable net tax liability," defined as the difference in net income tax with and without the gain from the farmland sale.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Reduces immediate tax burden for sellers of farmland to qualified farmers, potentially increasing land transfer to active farmers.
- Encourages long-term farmland preservation through mandatory 10-year farming-use restrictions.
- May increase administrative oversight for IRS due to installment tracking and covenant enforcement.
- Could affect tax revenue timing, deferring collections over four years.

sections.section: SEC. 70438. EXTENSION OF RULES FOR TREATMENT OF CERTAIN DISASTERRELATED PERSONAL CASUALTY LOSSES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter D--Permanent Investments in Small Business and Rural America
sections.summary:
Policy Change: Updates the reference date in Section 301 of the Taxpayer Certainty and Disaster Tax Relief Act of 2020 to the enactment date of the current section, for purposes of applying Section 304(b) of the same Act.

Dollar Amounts: Not specified.

Downstream Effects: Extends or reactivates tax relief provisions under Section 301 by resetting the applicable enactment date, potentially allowing additional taxpayers to qualify for relief or extending the window for eligible claims.

sections.section: SEC. 70439. RESTORATION OF TAXABLE REIT SUBSIDIARY ASSET TEST.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 4--INVESTING IN AMERICAN FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SMALL BUSINESSES
sections.subchapter: Subchapter D--Permanent Investments in Small Business and Rural America
sections.summary:
1. Policy Change: Increases the limit in Section 856(c)(4)(B)(ii) from 20% to 25%.

2. Effective Date: Applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2025.

3. Downstream Effects: Allows Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) to hold up to 25% of their assets in securities of one or more taxable REIT subsidiaries (TRSs), up from the current 20% cap, potentially enabling greater investment flexibility and expanded use of TRSs.

sections.section: SEC. 70501. TERMINATION OF PREVIOUSLY-OWNED CLEAN VEHICLE CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary: Section 25E(g) amendment changes the expiration date of the provision from December 31, 2032, to September 30, 2025. This shortens the duration of the policy by over seven years, potentially reducing associated federal expenditures and limiting the availability of related tax credits or benefits beyond FY2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70502. TERMINATION OF CLEAN VEHICLE CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**:
   - The eligibility date for the clean vehicle tax credit under IRC Section 30D is changed from vehicles "placed in service after December 31, 2032" to vehicles "acquired after September 30, 2025".
   - Several clauses in Section 30D(e)(1)(B) and Section 30D(e)(2)(B) are removed or modified to streamline the eligibility criteria:
     - Clause (v) in 30D(e)(1)(B) is repealed.
     - Clauses (iv) through (vi) in 30D(e)(2)(B) are repealed.

2. **Dollar Amounts**:
   - No specific dollar amounts are mentioned in this section.

3. **Downstream Effects**:
   - Accelerates the applicability of new eligibility rules for the clean vehicle tax credit to vehicles acquired after September 30, 2025, potentially affecting consumer purchasing behavior and manufacturer compliance timelines.
   - Simplifies the statutory language by removing multiple eligibility conditions, which may reduce administrative complexity for both taxpayers and the IRS.

sections.section: SEC. 70503. TERMINATION OF QUALIFIED COMMERCIAL CLEAN VEHICLES CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary:
Policy change: The expiration date for the Section 45W tax credit is moved up from December 31, 2032, to September 30, 2025.

Dollar amounts: No specific dollar amounts are changed in this section, but the earlier termination will reduce total outlays or tax expenditures associated with the credit.

Downstream effects: Shortens the availability of the Section 45W credit for qualified commercial clean vehicles by over seven years, potentially reducing the incentive for fleet electrification and impacting manufacturers and purchasers planning to utilize the credit beyond FY2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70504. TERMINATION OF ALTERNATIVE FUEL VEHICLE REFUELING PROPERTY CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary:
Policy change: The expiration date for the Section 30C alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit is moved up from December 31, 2032, to June 30, 2026.

Dollar amounts: No specific dollar amounts are changed in this section, but the earlier termination date reduces the duration of the tax credit availability.

Downstream effects: Shortens the window for taxpayers to claim the credit, potentially reducing investment in alternative fuel infrastructure after mid-2026 and lowering projected federal tax expenditures associated with the credit.

sections.section: SEC. 70505. TERMINATION OF ENERGY EFFICIENT HOME IMPROVEMENT CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
   - The eligibility period for the Section 25C residential energy efficiency tax credit is revised to apply only to property placed in service after December 31, 2025.
   - The definition of qualifying oil furnaces and hot water boilers under Section 25C(d)(2)(C) is updated to require:
     (i) compliance with 2021 Energy Star efficiency criteria, and
     (ii) manufacturer rating for use with fuel blends containing at least 20% eligible fuel.

2. Dollar Amounts:
   - No specific dollar amounts are mentioned in this section.

3. Downstream Effects:
   - Limits tax credit eligibility to newer installations post-2025, potentially reducing short-term claims.
   - Encourages adoption of higher-efficiency and renewable-compatible oil heating systems, potentially influencing manufacturer product lines and consumer purchasing decisions.

sections.section: SEC. 70506. TERMINATION OF RESIDENTIAL CLEAN ENERGY CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- The eligibility for the residential clean energy credit under Section 25D is revised to apply to expenditures made after December 31, 2025, rather than to property placed in service after December 31, 2034.
- The credit rate structure is simplified: the 30% credit rate is retained without future phasedown. Prior phasedown provisions (paragraphs (4) and (5)) are eliminated.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- The residential clean energy credit remains at 30% of qualified expenditures; no new dollar amounts are introduced.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Extending eligibility to expenditures made after 2025 may accelerate project planning and spending.
- Eliminating the phasedown schedule provides long-term certainty for taxpayers and clean energy markets, potentially increasing investment in residential clean energy systems.

sections.section: SEC. 70507. TERMINATION OF ENERGY EFFICIENT COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS DEDUCTION.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary:
1. Policy Change: Section 179D is amended to include a termination clause.  
2. Effective Date: The deduction will no longer apply to property whose construction begins after June 30, 2026.  
3. Downstream Effects: Eliminates eligibility for the energy-efficient commercial buildings deduction under Section 179D for projects starting after the cutoff date, potentially reducing incentives for energy-efficient construction beginning in FY2027 and beyond.

sections.section: SEC. 70508. TERMINATION OF NEW ENERGY EFFICIENT HOME CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary:
Policy Change: The expiration date for the Section 45L tax credit is moved up from December 31, 2032, to June 30, 2026.

Dollar Amounts: No direct dollar amounts specified in the amendment, but the change shortens the availability of the credit by 6.5 years.

Downstream Effects: Reduces the duration during which homebuilders can claim the energy-efficient home credit, potentially decreasing the total federal outlay for this incentive and possibly reducing the number of energy-efficient homes built after mid-2026.

sections.section: SEC. 70509. TERMINATION OF COST RECOVERY FOR ENERGY PROPERTY.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes: Removes subclause (I) from Section 168(e)(3)(B)(vi) of the Internal Revenue Code, which previously defined certain energy property eligible for 5-year depreciation. Remaining subclauses are renumbered.

2. Dollar Amounts: None specified.

3. Downstream Effects: Alters eligibility criteria for energy property qualifying for accelerated depreciation under MACRS; may reduce tax incentives for certain energy projects starting construction after December 31, 2024.

sections.section: SEC. 70510. MODIFICATIONS OF ZERO-EMISSION NUCLEAR POWER PRODUCTION CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
   - Amends Section 45U(c) to disallow the clean hydrogen production tax credit for certain foreign entities.
   - Immediately disqualifies "specified foreign entities" (as defined in 7701(a)(51)(B)) from claiming the credit for tax years beginning after enactment.
   - Disqualifies "foreign-influenced entities" (as defined in 7701(a)(51)(D), excluding clause (i)(II)) from claiming the credit starting two years after enactment.

2. Dollar Amounts:
   - No specific dollar amounts are stated in this section.

3. Downstream Effects:
   - Reduces eligibility for the Section 45U hydrogen production credit, potentially decreasing total federal outlays for the credit.
   - May deter foreign-influenced or foreign-controlled entities from investing in U.S.-based clean hydrogen projects.
   - Could shift investment and ownership structures to maintain eligibility for the credit.

sections.section: SEC. 70511. TERMINATION OF CLEAN HYDROGEN PRODUCTION CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary: Section 45V(c)(3)(C) changes the termination date for eligibility of the clean hydrogen production tax credit from January 1, 2033, to January 1, 2028. This accelerates the phase-out timeline by five years, potentially reducing the total federal expenditure on the credit and affecting investment timelines and project viability for hydrogen producers relying on the credit.

sections.section: SEC. 70512. TERMINATION AND RESTRICTIONS ON CLEAN ELECTRICITY PRODUCTION CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Section 45Y clean electricity production credit is terminated for wind and solar facilities placed in service after December 31, 2027.
- Facilities beginning construction after December 31, 2025, are disqualified from the credit if they receive "material assistance" from prohibited foreign entities.
- No credit is allowed if the taxpayer is a specified foreign entity or foreign-influenced entity.
- Definitions and thresholds are established for determining "material assistance" from prohibited foreign entities, including cost ratios and safe harbor rules.
- Taxpayers leasing residential wind or solar property to third parties are disqualified from claiming the credit.
- Greenhouse gas emissions rates may be determined using existing lifecycle assessment studies.
- "Nuclear energy communities" are expanded to include areas with significant nuclear-related employment for advanced nuclear facilities.
- Prohibits transfer of credits to specified foreign entities.
- Extends the statute of limitations to 6 years for errors related to material assistance determinations.
- Imposes accuracy-related penalties for disallowed energy credits due to overstated material assistance cost ratios.
- Establishes penalties for suppliers providing false certifications regarding foreign entity involvement.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- Material assistance cost ratio thresholds for disqualification vary by year and component:
  - For qualified facilities: 40% in 2026, increasing to 60% after 2029.
  - For energy storage: 55% in 2026, increasing to 75% after 2029.
  - For solar components: 50% in 2026, increasing to 85% after 2029.
  - For wind components: 85% in 2026, 90% in 2027.
  - For inverters: 50% in 2026, increasing to 70% after 2029.
  - For battery components: 60% in 2026, increasing to 85% after 2029.
  - For critical minerals: 0% before 2030, increasing to 50% after 2032.
- Penalty for false supplier certification: greater of 10% of underpayment or $5,000.
- Substantial understatement threshold for energy credit disallowance reduced to 1% of tax liability or $100,000.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Wind and solar projects must begin construction before the 12-month post-enactment deadline to remain eligible for credits.
- Developers must ensure supply chains are free of material assistance from prohibited foreign entities to qualify for credits.
- Increased compliance burden for taxpayers and suppliers, including documentation and certification requirements.
- Publicly traded companies face additional scrutiny regarding foreign ownership and influence.
- IRS will issue guidance and safe harbor tables by December 31, 2026, to assist in compliance.
- Potential reduction in foreign-sourced components in clean energy projects.
- New penalties and extended audit windows increase enforcement risk for taxpayers and suppliers.

sections.section: SEC. 70513. TERMINATION AND RESTRICTIONS ON CLEAN ELECTRICITY INVESTMENT CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Section 48E credit eligibility is terminated for wind and solar facilities placed in service after December 31, 2027, unless the facility includes energy storage technology.
- Facilities or property receiving material assistance from “prohibited foreign entities” (as defined in §7701(a)(52)) are excluded from qualifying for the §48E credit if construction begins after December 31, 2025.
- Taxpayers that are specified foreign entities or foreign-influenced entities (per §7701(a)(51)) are ineligible for §48E credits.
- A 100% recapture of previously claimed §48E credits is triggered if a specified taxpayer makes payments to prohibited foreign entities within 10 years of placing the property in service.
- No §48E credit is allowed for leased wind or solar property (as defined in §25D(d)(1) or (4)) if the taxpayer leases the property to a third party during the tax year.
- Domestic content thresholds for §48E credits are phased in:
  - 40% (20% offshore wind) for construction before June 16, 2025
  - 45% (27.5% offshore wind) for construction from June 16, 2025 to December 31, 2025
  - 50% (35% offshore wind) for construction in 2026
  - 55% for construction after December 31, 2026
- Energy credit percentage for certain energy property under §48(a)(2)(A)(ii) is reduced from 2% to 0%, with no future adjustments allowed.
- §48E is extended to qualified fuel cell property (as defined in §48(c)(1), excluding (E)), with a fixed 30% credit and no bonus adjustments.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific appropriations or funding amounts are stated; changes affect eligibility for tax credits and recapture of claimed credits (100% recapture for violations involving prohibited foreign entities).

3. Downstream Effects:
- Wind and solar projects placed in service after 2027 will lose eligibility for §48E unless paired with energy storage, potentially reducing new standalone wind/solar investments.
- Developers may avoid sourcing materials or services from prohibited foreign entities to retain eligibility, impacting supply chain decisions.
- Foreign-influenced or foreign-controlled entities may be excluded from claiming clean energy credits, potentially reducing foreign investment in U.S. clean energy projects.
- Leasing models for residential wind/solar may become less attractive due to denial of credits.
- Increased domestic content requirements may shift procurement toward U.S.-based manufacturers, potentially increasing project costs or timelines.
- Fuel cell projects gain access to §48E credits, potentially increasing investment in hydrogen and fuel cell technologies.

sections.section: SEC. 70514. PHASE-OUT AND RESTRICTIONS ON ADVANCED MANUFACTURING PRODUCTION CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Redefines "sale" for eligible components: A component integrated into another component at the same facility is treated as sold if the final product is sold to an unrelated party, provided 65%+ of direct material costs for the final product are from U.S.-sourced components.
- Phases out tax credits for critical minerals (excluding metallurgical coal) from 2031–2033; terminates them after 2033.
- Ends credits for wind energy components after December 31, 2027.
- Ends credits for metallurgical coal after December 31, 2029.
- Disqualifies components from credit eligibility if they include material assistance from prohibited foreign entities (PFEs) for tax years beginning after enactment.
- Disallows credits for taxpayers that are specified foreign entities or foreign-influenced entities.
- Expands the definition of "battery module" to include essential energy collection equipment (e.g., current collector assemblies, voltage sense harnesses).
- Adds metallurgical coal to the list of applicable critical minerals for credit eligibility, regardless of production location.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- Metallurgical coal receives a 2.5% credit rate (compared to 10% for other applicable critical minerals).

3. Downstream Effects:
- Encourages domestic sourcing of components to qualify for credits.
- Reduces and eventually eliminates incentives for critical mineral production post-2030 (except metallurgical coal).
- Removes incentives for wind energy components after 2027.
- Limits eligibility for credits based on foreign entity involvement, potentially excluding foreign-controlled or influenced manufacturers.
- Expands credit eligibility for battery modules with additional essential equipment.
- Incentivizes metallurgical coal production for steelmaking through inclusion in the credit program.

sections.section: SEC. 70515. RESTRICTION ON THE EXTENSION OF ADVANCED ENERGY PROJECT CREDIT PROGRAM.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Termination of Green New Deal Subsidies
sections.summary:
1. Policy Change: Amends Section 48C(e)(3)(C) to eliminate the provision that previously allowed an increase in the credit allocation amount; the credit allocation amount shall no longer be increased.

2. Dollar Amounts: No specific dollar amounts are stated in this section, but the change limits the total allocation of credits under Section 48C.

3. Downstream Effects: Caps the total amount of qualifying advanced energy project credits available, potentially reducing future federal tax expenditures and limiting the number of projects that can receive the credit.

sections.section: SEC. 70521. EXTENSION AND MODIFICATION OF CLEAN FUEL PRODUCTION CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Enhancement of America-first Energy Policy
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Section 45Z(f)(1)(A) amended to prohibit clean fuel production credits for fuels using feedstocks not exclusively from the U.S., Mexico, or Canada, effective for fuel produced after Dec. 31, 2025.
- Section 45Z(b)(1) amended to prohibit negative emissions rates for transportation fuels, except for fuels derived from animal manure, effective after Dec. 31, 2025.
- Emission rates must exclude indirect land use change emissions and must include specific rates for different types of animal manure; manure-derived fuels may have negative emissions rates.
- Clean Fuel Production Credit under Section 45Z extended from Dec. 31, 2027, to Dec. 31, 2029.
- Section 45Z(d)(5) amended to prevent double crediting for fuels already receiving a credit under Section 45Z.
- Treasury authorized to issue rules to prevent related-party transactions from circumventing unrelated sales requirements under Section 45Z(f)(3).
- Coordination between Section 6426(k) and Section 45Z to prevent double credits for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF); SAF credit under 6426(k) terminates after Sept. 30, 2025.
- Definition of SAF under Section 45Z(a)(3) revised to exclude palm fatty acid distillates and petroleum; special SAF credit rates eliminated.
- Registration requirement for producers of fuel eligible for Section 45Z credit updated to reference Section 40B instead of 6426(k)(3).
- Small agri-biodiesel producer credit under Section 40A(b)(4) increased from $0.10 to $0.20 per gallon, extended through Dec. 31, 2026, and allowed in addition to Section 45Z credit.
- Transferability of small agri-biodiesel producer credit added under Section 6418(f)(1)(A)(xii).
- Section 45Z(f) amended to disallow credits for specified foreign entities and foreign-influenced entities (as defined in Section 7701(a)(51)) starting immediately or within two years, respectively.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- Small agri-biodiesel producer credit increased from $0.10 to $0.20 per gallon.
- Elimination of special SAF credit rates: $1.75 and $0.35 per gallon removed from Section 45Z(a)(3)(A).
- No new dollar amounts introduced for other provisions; changes primarily affect eligibility and definitions.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Limits eligibility for clean fuel credits to North American feedstocks, potentially excluding imports from other regions.
- Prohibits use of negative emissions rates (except for manure-based fuels), which may reduce credit amounts for certain fuels.
- Exclusion of indirect land use change emissions may increase eligibility for certain biofuels.
- Extension of Section 45Z credit to 2029 provides longer-term certainty for clean fuel producers.
- Coordination and termination of SAF credits under 6426(k) avoids double-dipping and shifts SAF incentives to Section 45Z.
- Increased and extended small agri-biodiesel producer credit incentivizes domestic biodiesel production.
- Restrictions on foreign and foreign-influenced entities limit access to credits, potentially reshaping investment and ownership structures in clean fuel production.

sections.section: SEC. 70522. RESTRICTIONS ON CARBON OXIDE SEQUESTRATION CREDIT.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Enhancement of America-first Energy Policy
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes:**
   - **Foreign Entity Restriction:** Taxpayers classified as specified foreign entities or foreign-influenced entities (per Section 7701 definitions) are ineligible for the Section 45Q carbon oxide sequestration credit for tax years beginning after enactment.
   - **Utilization Parity:** Section 45Q(a)(3) is revised to treat three types of carbon oxide use—secure geological storage, use in enhanced oil/gas recovery with storage, and other qualified utilization (per 45Q(f)(5))—with equal credit eligibility.
   - **Elimination of Redundant Provisions:** Paragraph 45Q(a)(4) is repealed; references to it are removed throughout the statute.
   - **Credit Amount Adjustments:** 
     - For carbon oxide utilization (non-EOR), the base credit is set at $17/metric ton for tax years 2025–2026.
     - Starting in 2027, the $17 amount is adjusted for inflation using a modified Section 43(b)(3)(B) formula (base year changed to 2025).
     - For EOR and secure storage, the credit is $36/metric ton, also subject to inflation adjustment.

2. **Dollar Amounts:**
   - $17/metric ton for general carbon oxide utilization (2025–2026).
   - $36/metric ton for EOR and secure geological storage.
   - Post-2026, both amounts are inflation-adjusted using a 2025 base year.

3. **Downstream Effects:**
   - Excludes foreign-influenced or specified foreign entities from accessing 45Q credits, potentially reducing foreign investment in U.S. carbon capture projects.
   - Equalizes credit treatment across different carbon oxide uses, incentivizing broader deployment of carbon utilization technologies beyond EOR.
   - Inflation adjustments ensure long-term value retention of credits, improving financial predictability for project developers.
   - Repeal of paragraph (a)(4) simplifies statutory structure and removes duplicative provisions.

sections.section: SEC. 70523. INTANGIBLE DRILLING AND DEVELOPMENT COSTS TAKEN INTO ACCOUNT FOR PURPOSES OF COMPUTING ADJUSTED FINANCIAL STATEMENT INCOME.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Enhancement of America-first Energy Policy
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Modifies Section 56A(c)(13) to adjust the calculation of adjusted financial statement income (AFSI) for corporate alternative minimum tax (AMT) purposes.
- Depreciation deductions under Section 167 for property under Section 168 are now subtracted from AFSI to the extent they are allowed in computing taxable income.
- Deductions for expenses under Section 263(c), including those under Sections 59(e) and 291(b)(2), are also subtracted from AFSI to the extent allowed in computing taxable income.
- Requires disregarding depreciation and depletion expenses reflected in financial statements for the same property when calculating AFSI.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are provided in the section; changes affect the calculation methodology for tax liability.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Reduces AFSI for corporate AMT purposes by aligning it more closely with taxable income, potentially lowering AMT liability for corporations with significant depreciation or intangible drilling cost deductions.
- May benefit capital-intensive and extractive industries by reducing their AMT exposure.
- Effective for tax years beginning after December 31, 2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70524. INCOME FROM HYDROGEN STORAGE, CARBON CAPTURE, ADVANCED NUCLEAR, HYDROPOWER, AND GEOTHERMAL ENERGY ADDED TO QUALIFYING INCOME OF CERTAIN PUBLICLY TRADED PARTNERSHIPS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Enhancement of America-first Energy Policy
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**:
   - Expands the definition of "qualifying income" under Section 7704(d)(1)(E) for publicly traded partnerships (PTPs) to include:
     - Income and gains from:
       - Transportation or storage of fuels eligible for credits under Sections 6426(b)-(e), (k), including alcohol fuels, biodiesel, and sustainable aviation fuel.
       - Transportation or storage of liquefied or compressed hydrogen.
       - Generation, availability, or storage of electricity at qualified carbon capture facilities (as defined in Section 45Q(d)), or carbon dioxide capture at such facilities.
       - Electricity production from advanced nuclear facilities (Section 45J(d)(2)).
       - Electricity or thermal energy production using certain qualified energy resources (Section 45(c)(1)(D) or (H)).
       - Operation of specific energy properties under Section 48(a)(3)(A)(iii) or (vii), regardless of construction start date.

2. **Dollar Amounts**:
   - No specific dollar amounts are included in this section.

3. **Downstream Effects**:
   - Broadens eligibility for PTPs to receive favorable tax treatment by including additional clean energy and carbon capture activities.
   - Encourages investment in hydrogen infrastructure, carbon capture, advanced nuclear, and renewable energy by allowing related income to qualify as passive-type income.
   - May increase the number of energy-related PTPs and associated capital flows into clean energy sectors starting in tax year 2026.

sections.section: SEC. 70525. ALLOW FOR PAYMENTS TO CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS WHO DYE FUEL.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Enhancement of America-first Energy Policy
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Establishes new Section 6435 allowing refunds (without interest) of previously paid fuel excise taxes under Section 4081 for indelibly dyed diesel fuel or kerosene that is exempt under Section 4082(a), provided the fuel is removed from a terminal and meets eligibility criteria.
- Defines "eligible indelibly dyed diesel fuel or kerosene" as fuel on which tax under Section 4081 was paid (and not refunded or credited) and which qualifies for exemption under Section 4082(a).
- Adds civil penalty provisions for excessive claims under Section 6435, referencing Section 6675.
- Updates Sections 6206, 6430, and 6675 to include references to Section 6435.
- Adds Section 6435 to the table of sections in Subchapter B of Chapter 65.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- Refund amount equals the tax previously paid under Section 4081 for eligible dyed fuel; no specific dollar figure is stated.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Enables fuel distributors or terminal operators to claim refunds on taxed dyed fuel that is later determined to be tax-exempt, improving cash flow for compliant entities.
- Introduces potential for increased refund claims, requiring IRS oversight to prevent excessive or fraudulent claims.
- May incentivize more accurate classification and handling of dyed fuel to ensure eligibility for refunds.

sections.section: SEC. 70531. MODIFICATIONS TO DE MINIMIS ENTRY PRIVILEGE FOR COMMERCIAL SHIPMENTS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 5--ENDING GREEN NEW DEAL SPENDING, PROMOTING AMERICA-FIRST ENERGY, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Other Reforms
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**:
   - Adds a new civil penalty under Section 321 of the Tariff Act of 1930 for misuse of de minimis entry privileges (i.e., low-value shipments). Violators using this privilege to import goods in violation of other customs laws face new penalties.
   - Repeals the commercial shipment exception under Section 321(a)(2), which previously allowed certain low-value commercial shipments to enter duty-free under de minimis rules.
   - Repeals the newly added civil penalty provision (subsection (c)) effective July 1, 2027.

2. **Dollar Amounts**:
   - Civil penalties: Up to $5,000 for the first violation; up to $10,000 for each subsequent violation.

3. **Downstream Effects**:
   - Increased enforcement and deterrence against misuse of de minimis entry privileges.
   - Potential reduction in low-value commercial shipments exploiting de minimis thresholds.
   - Revenue impact from penalties and reduced duty-free imports, though specific fiscal estimates are not provided in this section.

sections.section: SEC. 70601. MODIFICATION AND EXTENSION OF LIMITATION ON EXCESS BUSINESS LOSSES OF NONCORPORATE TAXPAYERS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 6--ENHANCING DEDUCTION AND INCOME TAX CREDIT GUARDRAILS, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
   - The limitation on excess business losses under IRC § 461(l)(1) is made permanent by removing the sunset date of January 1, 2029.
   - The inflation adjustment base year for calculating the threshold for excess business losses is updated from 2017 to 2024.
   - The starting point for inflation adjustments is changed from December 31, 2018, to December 31, 2025.

2. Dollar Amounts:
   - No specific dollar amounts are stated in this section, but the threshold for excess business losses (previously $250,000 for individuals and $500,000 for joint filers, indexed for inflation) will now be adjusted using 2024 as the base year starting in 2026.

3. Downstream Effects:
   - The excess business loss limitation becomes a permanent feature of the tax code, affecting non-corporate taxpayers indefinitely.
   - Future inflation adjustments to the loss limitation thresholds may result in different allowable loss amounts due to the change in the base year, potentially reducing allowable deductions relative to prior projections.
   - Taxpayers with large business losses will continue to face limitations on deductibility beyond 2028, impacting tax planning and net operating loss carryforward strategies.

sections.section: SEC. 70602. TREATMENT OF PAYMENTS FROM PARTNERSHIPS TO PARTNERS FOR PROPERTY OR SERVICES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 6--ENHANCING DEDUCTION AND INCOME TAX CREDIT GUARDRAILS, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes: Amends IRC Section 707(a)(2) by replacing the phrase “Under regulations prescribed” with “Except as provided,” altering the statutory language to potentially limit or clarify the scope of regulatory authority or exceptions.

2. Dollar Amounts: None specified.

3. Downstream Effects: Applies the amendment prospectively to services performed and property transferred after the enactment date, with no retroactive effect. Preserves existing interpretations for transactions occurring before enactment, preventing reinterpretation of prior payments or transfers under the amended language.

sections.section: SEC. 70603. EXCESSIVE EMPLOYEE REMUNERATION FROM CONTROLLED GROUP MEMBERS AND ALLOCATION OF DEDUCTION.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 6--ENHANCING DEDUCTION AND INCOME TAX CREDIT GUARDRAILS, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Expands Section 162(m) to apply aggregation rules to members of a controlled group of corporations.
- Introduces the term "specified covered employee" to replace "covered employee" when applying deduction limits across a controlled group.
- Requires each member of a controlled group to apply the $1 million deduction limit proportionally (allocable limitation amount) when total remuneration to a specified covered employee exceeds $1 million.
- Defines "controlled group" using Section 414 aggregation rules and broadens the definition of covered employees to include individuals across the entire group.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- Maintains the $1,000,000 deduction limit for applicable employee remuneration.
- Allocates the $1,000,000 limit proportionally among group members based on each member’s share of total remuneration paid to the specified covered employee.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Publicly held corporations and their affiliates in a controlled group will face tighter limits on deducting executive compensation.
- May reduce allowable tax deductions for executive pay across affiliated entities.
- Increases administrative complexity in tracking and allocating compensation limits across corporate groups.
- Effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70604. EXCISE TAX ON CERTAIN REMITTANCE TRANSFERS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 6--ENHANCING DEDUCTION AND INCOME TAX CREDIT GUARDRAILS, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- A new 1% federal tax is imposed on remittance transfers involving cash or similar physical instruments.
- The tax is paid by the sender and collected by the remittance transfer provider, who must remit it quarterly to the IRS.
- If the sender fails to pay, the provider becomes secondarily liable for the tax.
- Transfers funded via U.S.-issued debit cards, credit cards, or accounts at regulated financial institutions are exempt.
- Applies only to transfers defined under the Electronic Fund Transfer Act.
- Remittance transfers are treated as financing transactions under anti-conduit rules (IRC §7701(l)).

2. Dollar Amounts:
- Tax rate: 1% of the remittance transfer amount.
- No specific revenue projections provided in this section.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Increases cost of cash-based remittance transfers, potentially discouraging their use.
- May incentivize use of bank accounts or U.S.-issued cards for remittances to avoid the tax.
- Imposes new compliance and reporting burdens on remittance transfer providers.
- Could shift remittance behavior toward formal financial channels or reduce overall remittance volume.

sections.section: SEC. 70605. ENFORCEMENT PROVISIONS WITH RESPECT TO COVID-RELATED EMPLOYEE RETENTION CREDITS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 6--ENHANCING DEDUCTION AND INCOME TAX CREDIT GUARDRAILS, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Imposes a $1,000 penalty per violation on COVID-ERTC promoters who fail to meet due diligence requirements similar to those under IRC §6695(g).
- Defines “COVID-ERTC promoter” as any person providing paid aid, assistance, or advice on COVID-ERTC documents, with thresholds based on gross receipts (20% or 50%, or $500,000 in receipts).
- Excludes certified professional employer organizations from the definition of COVID-ERTC promoter.
- Limits COVID-ERTC claims: no credit or refund allowed after enactment unless filed by January 31, 2024.
- Extends IRS assessment period for COVID-ERTC claims to 6 years from the latest of: original return filing, deemed filing date, or claim date.
- Aligns refund claim period for deductions related to improperly claimed ERTC wages with the extended assessment period.
- Expands penalty under IRC §6676 to include erroneous employment tax refund claims, not just income tax.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- $1,000 penalty per due diligence failure by COVID-ERTC promoters.
- COVID-ERTC promoter thresholds: over 20% or 50% of gross receipts, or over $500,000 in COVID-ERTC-related receipts.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Increases compliance burden on tax advisors and consultants handling COVID-ERTC claims.
- Restricts late COVID-ERTC claims, potentially reducing future IRS refund liabilities.
- Extends IRS enforcement window, allowing more time to audit and assess improper COVID-ERTC claims.
- Broadens IRS penalty authority to deter erroneous employment tax refund claims.

sections.section: SEC. 70606. SOCIAL SECURITY NUMBER REQUIREMENT FOR AMERICAN OPPORTUNITY AND LIFETIME LEARNING CREDITS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 6--ENHANCING DEDUCTION AND INCOME TAX CREDIT GUARDRAILS, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
   - Taxpayers must include their own Social Security Number (SSN) on tax returns to claim the American Opportunity Tax Credit (AOTC).
   - If the credit is claimed for someone other than the taxpayer or their spouse, the name and SSN of that individual must also be included.
   - Taxpayers must report the Employer Identification Number (EIN) of the educational institution receiving qualified tuition payments.
   - The term "TIN" is replaced with "social security number or employer identification number" for purposes of identifying mathematical or clerical errors under Section 6213(g)(2)(J).

2. Dollar Amounts:
   - No specific dollar amounts are mentioned in this section.

3. Downstream Effects:
   - Increased compliance requirements for taxpayers claiming the AOTC.
   - Potential increase in IRS enforcement and error correction activity due to expanded identification requirements.
   - May reduce improper or fraudulent claims of the AOTC by requiring verifiable identification data.
   - Applies to tax years beginning after December 31, 2025.

sections.section: SEC. 70607. TASK FORCE ON THE REPLACEMENT OF DIRECT FILE.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle A--Tax
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 6--ENHANCING DEDUCTION AND INCOME TAX CREDIT GUARDRAILS, AND OTHER REFORMS
sections.summary:
**Policy Changes:**
- Mandates the Department of the Treasury to deliver a report to Congress within 90 days of enactment.
- Report must assess: 
  1. Costs of enhancing or establishing public-private partnerships to provide free tax filing for up to 70% of taxpayers (by AGI), replacing existing IRS direct e-file programs.
  2. Taxpayer preferences between government-run and private-sector free filing services.
  3. Feasibility and standardization of a new taxpayer filing approach across providers.
  4. Cost estimates for developing and operating a free direct e-file system, including tiered options by AGI and return complexity.

**Dollar Amounts:**
- $15,000,000 appropriated for FY 2026, available through September 30, 2026.

**Downstream Effects:**
- Potential phase-out of IRS-run direct e-file programs.
- Possible establishment of a new public-private tax filing infrastructure.
- Could lead to a government-funded e-file system with differentiated service levels based on taxpayer income and return complexity.
- May influence future legislation on taxpayer service delivery models.

sections.section: SEC. 71101. MORATORIUM ON IMPLEMENTATION OF RULE RELATING TO ELIGIBILITY AND ENROLLMENT IN MEDICARE SAVINGS PROGRAMS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Reducing Fraud and Improving Enrollment Processes
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**: Prohibits HHS from implementing, administering, or enforcing specific regulatory amendments from the CMS final rule titled "Streamlining Medicaid; Medicare Savings Program Eligibility Determination and Enrollment" (88 Fed. Reg. 65230) for five specified sections of 42 CFR from enactment through September 30, 2034.

2. **Dollar Amounts**: Appropriates $1,000,000 in FY 2026 to the CMS Administrator, available until expended.

3. **Downstream Effects**: Delays or halts regulatory changes intended to streamline Medicaid and Medicare Savings Program eligibility and enrollment processes for a decade, potentially maintaining existing administrative burdens and eligibility procedures. The $1 million appropriation supports implementation of this legislative section and section 71102.

sections.section: SEC. 71102. MORATORIUM ON IMPLEMENTATION OF RULE RELATING TO ELIGIBILITY AND ENROLLMENT FOR MEDICAID, CHIP, AND THE BASIC HEALTH PROGRAM.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Reducing Fraud and Improving Enrollment Processes
sections.summary:
**Policy Changes:**  
Prohibits the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) from implementing, administering, or enforcing specific regulatory amendments from the CMS final rule published on April 2, 2024 (89 Fed. Reg. 22780), related to streamlining application, eligibility, enrollment, and renewal processes for Medicaid, CHIP, and the Basic Health Program. The prohibition applies to specified sections of 42 CFR Parts 431, 435, 447, and 457.

**Dollar Amounts:**  
No direct appropriations or cost figures are specified in this section.

**Downstream Effects:**  
- Delays or prevents implementation of streamlined eligibility and enrollment processes intended by the April 2024 CMS rule.
- Maintains current administrative procedures and documentation requirements for Medicaid, CHIP, and Basic Health Program eligibility and enrollment through at least FY2034.
- Potentially increases administrative burden on states and applicants by preserving more complex or redundant processes.
- May affect enrollment continuity and access to coverage for eligible individuals due to halted reforms.

sections.section: SEC. 71103. REDUCING DUPLICATE ENROLLMENT UNDER THE MEDICAID AND CHIP PROGRAMS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Reducing Fraud and Improving Enrollment Processes
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- States must implement a process by Jan 1, 2027, to regularly obtain and update Medicaid enrollees’ address information using reliable sources (e.g., USPS data, managed care entities).
- By Oct 1, 2029, states must submit monthly data (including SSNs and other identifiers) to a federal system to detect and prevent simultaneous Medicaid enrollment in multiple states.
- The Secretary of HHS must establish this federal system by Oct 1, 2029, and issue standards for data protection and privacy.
- States must act on system findings to verify residency and disenroll individuals not residing in the state unless exempted.
- Managed care contracts must require transmission of verified address data to states starting Jan 1, 2027.
- The Public Assistance Reporting Information System (PARIS) will be supplemented by the new federal system for address verification; states may be exempted from using PARIS if using the new system.
- These requirements are extended to CHIP programs via amendments to relevant sections.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- $10 million appropriated in FY 2026 for system establishment.
- $20 million appropriated in FY 2029 for system maintenance.
- Funds are to remain available until expended.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Enhanced detection and prevention of dual-state Medicaid/CHIP enrollment.
- Improved accuracy of enrollee address data, reducing improper payments.
- Increased administrative burden on states and managed care entities to collect and report data.
- Potential disenrollment of individuals incorrectly enrolled in multiple states or with outdated residency information.

sections.section: SEC. 71104. ENSURING DECEASED INDIVIDUALS DO NOT REMAIN ENROLLED.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Reducing Fraud and Improving Enrollment Processes
sections.summary:
**Policy Changes:**
1. Adds a new Medicaid eligibility verification requirement under Section 1902(a)(89) of the Social Security Act, applicable to all U.S. states and D.C.
2. Requires states, beginning January 1, 2027, to conduct quarterly checks of Medicaid enrollees against the Death Master File (DMF) or a successor system to identify deceased individuals.
3. Mandates disenrollment of individuals confirmed deceased via the DMF and cessation of Medicaid payments for services rendered after death.
4. Requires immediate reinstatement of coverage, retroactive to the disenrollment date, for individuals erroneously identified as deceased.
5. Allows states to use additional electronic data sources for death verification, provided DMF checks are also conducted.

**Dollar Amounts:**
- No specific dollar amounts are cited in this section.

**Downstream Effects:**
1. Increased administrative burden on states to implement quarterly DMF checks and manage disenrollment/reinstatement processes.
2. Potential cost savings from reduced improper Medicaid payments to deceased individuals.
3. Risk of temporary loss of coverage for individuals misidentified as deceased, with required retroactive reinstatement.

sections.section: SEC. 71105. ENSURING DECEASED PROVIDERS DO NOT REMAIN ENROLLED.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Reducing Fraud and Improving Enrollment Processes
sections.summary:
**Policy Changes:**
- Requires states, starting January 1, 2028, to check the Death Master File during provider enrollment, reenrollment, or revalidation under Medicaid.
- Mandates quarterly checks thereafter to verify that enrolled providers or suppliers are not deceased.

**Dollar Amounts:**
- No specific dollar amounts are stated in this section.

**Downstream Effects:**
- Increased administrative responsibilities and potential IT system updates for state Medicaid programs.
- Potential cost savings by preventing payments to deceased providers.
- May reduce fraud and improper payments in Medicaid.

sections.section: SEC. 71106. PAYMENT REDUCTION RELATED TO CERTAIN ERRONEOUS EXCESS PAYMENTS UNDER MEDICAID.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Reducing Fraud and Improving Enrollment Processes
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**:
   - Allows Medicaid payment error audits to be conducted by either the Secretary of HHS or, optionally, by the State.
   - Limits the Secretary’s waiver authority for disallowing federal financial participation (FFP) in erroneous payments to the amount of erroneous payments exceeding the 3% allowable error rate.
   - Clarifies that "erroneous payments" include those made with insufficient information to confirm eligibility, and payments for services provided to individuals not eligible under the State plan or waiver.

2. **Dollar Amounts**:
   - No specific dollar amounts are provided, but the waiver cap is tied to the value of erroneous payments exceeding the 3% error threshold.

3. **Downstream Effects**:
   - States may have increased responsibility or flexibility in conducting Medicaid audits.
   - Tighter limits on federal waivers could increase state financial liability for Medicaid payment errors above the 3% threshold.
   - Expanded definition of erroneous payments may lead to more disallowances and increased scrutiny of eligibility verification processes.

Effective beginning FY 2030.

sections.section: SEC. 71107. ELIGIBILITY REDETERMINATIONS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Reducing Fraud and Improving Enrollment Processes
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Beginning in the first quarter after December 31, 2026, states must conduct Medicaid eligibility redeterminations every 6 months for individuals enrolled under section 1902(a)(10)(A)(i)(VIII) (i.e., the ACA Medicaid expansion group) and those covered under equivalent waiver plans.
- An exemption is provided for individuals described in section 1902(xx)(9)(A)(ii)(II).
- The definition of "State" includes all 50 states and the District of Columbia.
- HHS must issue implementation guidance within 180 days of enactment.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- $75,000,000 is appropriated for FY 2026 to the CMS Administrator for implementation, available until expended.

3. Downstream Effects:
- States will be required to increase the frequency of eligibility checks for the ACA expansion population, potentially leading to increased administrative costs and changes in enrollment continuity.
- CMS will receive dedicated funding to support implementation, including administrative systems, oversight, and guidance development.

sections.section: SEC. 71108. REVISING HOME EQUITY LIMIT FOR DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY FOR LONG-TERM CARE SERVICES UNDER THE MEDICAID PROGRAM.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Reducing Fraud and Improving Enrollment Processes
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes:**
   - States may now apply a higher home equity limit for Medicaid eligibility determinations for long-term care services.
   - For homes on agriculturally zoned lots, states may apply a higher limit than the standard.
   - For non-agricultural homes, states may elect to raise the home equity limit above the standard amount, up to a maximum of $1,000,000.
   - The amendments clarify that the home equity limit under Section 1917(f)(1) must be applied when determining Medicaid eligibility for nursing facility or other long-term care services.
   - States cannot bypass the home equity limit under Section 1917(f)(1) via income methodologies under Section 1902(r)(2).

2. **Dollar Amounts:**
   - The standard home equity limit remains at $500,000 (referenced as the amount in subparagraph (A)).
   - States may increase this limit up to $1,000,000 for both agricultural and non-agricultural homes.
   - Any indexed increases to the home equity limit are capped at $1,000,000.

3. **Downstream Effects:**
   - Potential expansion of Medicaid eligibility for individuals with higher home equity, particularly in high-cost housing markets or agricultural areas.
   - Increased state flexibility may lead to variation in Medicaid eligibility thresholds across states.
   - Possible budgetary impact due to increased enrollment in long-term care services under Medicaid starting January 1, 2028.

sections.section: SEC. 71109. ALIEN MEDICAID ELIGIBILITY.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Reducing Fraud and Improving Enrollment Processes
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Amends Medicaid eligibility rules under Section 1903(v) of the Social Security Act to restrict federal Medicaid payments, effective October 1, 2026, to individuals who are:
  (A) residents of the U.S. (including states, D.C., or territories), and
  (B) either U.S. citizens/nationals, lawful permanent residents, Cuban/Haitian entrants, or individuals lawfully residing under a Compact of Free Association.
- Applies the same restriction to CHIP via Section 2107(e)(1), incorporating the new Medicaid eligibility rule (Section 1903(v)(5)) into CHIP, with an exception for services under Section 2105(a)(1)(D)(ii).

2. Dollar Amounts:
- $15,000,000 appropriated in FY2026 to CMS for implementation, available until expended.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Limits federal Medicaid and CHIP funding for services provided to undocumented immigrants and certain non-qualified aliens starting FY2027.
- States may face increased uncompensated care costs or need to adjust eligibility systems.
- Potential reduction in Medicaid/CHIP enrollment among non-qualified immigrant populations.

sections.section: SEC. 71110. EXPANSION FMAP FOR EMERGENCY MEDICAID.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter A--Reducing Fraud and Improving Enrollment Processes
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**: Effective October 1, 2026, the FMAP (Federal Medical Assistance Percentage) for emergency medical services provided to undocumented immigrants under section 1903(v)(2) will be capped at the regular state-specific FMAP under section 1905(b), overriding enhanced FMAP rates under subsections (y) and (z).

2. **Dollar Amounts**: $1,000,000 is appropriated for FY 2026 to the CMS Administrator for implementation, available until expended.

3. **Downstream Effects**: States will no longer receive enhanced FMAP rates for emergency Medicaid services to undocumented immigrants, potentially increasing state Medicaid costs for these services starting in FY 2027.

sections.section: SEC. 71111. MORATORIUM ON IMPLEMENTATION OF RULE RELATING TO STAFFING STANDARDS FOR LONG-TERM CARE FACILITIES UNDER THE MEDICARE AND MEDICAID PROGRAMS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Preventing Wasteful Spending
sections.summary:
**Policy Changes:** Prohibits the Secretary of Health and Human Services from implementing, administering, or enforcing the amendments made by the CMS final rule (published May 10, 2024, 89 Fed. Reg. 40876) related to minimum staffing standards and Medicaid payment transparency reporting for long-term care facilities, specifically to 42 CFR §§ 483.5 and 483.35.

**Dollar Amounts:** Not specified in this section.

**Downstream Effects:** Delays enforcement of new federal staffing standards and Medicaid payment transparency requirements for long-term care facilities until at least September 30, 2034; may reduce compliance costs for facilities in the short term but could impact care quality and transparency initiatives.

sections.section: SEC. 71112. REDUCING STATE MEDICAID COSTS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Preventing Wasteful Spending
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes:**
   - Revises Medicaid retroactive eligibility under SSA §1902(a)(34):
     - For individuals eligible under ACA Medicaid expansion (1902(a)(10)(A)(i)(VIII)), retroactive coverage is limited to one month prior to the application month.
     - For all other Medicaid-eligible individuals, retroactive coverage is limited to two months prior to the application month (previously three months).
   - Updates SSA §1905(a) to align the definition of "medical assistance" with the new retroactive coverage limits.
   - Amends CHIP (SSA §2102(b)(1)(B)) to prohibit states from providing retroactive CHIP or pregnancy-related assistance for services furnished more than two months before the application month.

2. **Dollar Amounts:**
   - $10,000,000 appropriated in FY2026 to CMS for implementation, available until expended.

3. **Downstream Effects:**
   - Reduces the period of retroactive Medicaid and CHIP coverage, potentially decreasing state and federal Medicaid/CHIP expenditures.
   - May result in increased uncompensated care costs for providers and reduced access to retroactive coverage for beneficiaries.
   - Requires administrative updates and system changes at CMS and state Medicaid agencies, funded by the $10 million appropriation.
   - Changes apply to applications submitted on or after the first day of the first quarter following December 31, 2026.

sections.section: SEC. 71113. FEDERAL PAYMENTS TO PROHIBITED ENTITIES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter B--Preventing Wasteful Spending
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**:
   - For one year from enactment, federal direct spending under Medicaid (Title XIX of the Social Security Act) is prohibited from being used to pay any "prohibited entity" for services, either directly or through contracts with managed care or prepaid health plans.
   - "Prohibited entities" are defined as 501(c)(3) tax-exempt essential community providers primarily engaged in family planning and reproductive health that provide abortions, except in cases of rape, incest, or life-endangering conditions.
   - The restriction applies only to entities (including affiliates, subsidiaries, and clinics) that received over $800,000 in combined federal and state Medicaid funds in FY2023.

2. **Dollar Amounts**:
   - $1,000,000 is appropriated to CMS for FY2026 for implementation, available until expended.
   - The $800,000 threshold in FY2023 Medicaid payments determines applicability of the funding restriction.

3. **Downstream Effects**:
   - Certain large reproductive health providers, including affiliates, may lose Medicaid funding for one year.
   - States and Medicaid managed care organizations will need to adjust provider networks and contracts to comply.
   - CMS will incur administrative costs for implementation and enforcement using the appropriated $1 million.

sections.section: SEC. 71114. SUNSETTING INCREASED FMAP INCENTIVE.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Stopping Abusive Financing Practices
sections.summary:
**Policy Change:** Amends Section 1905(ii)(3) of the Social Security Act to add a new eligibility condition for enhanced federal Medicaid matching funds. States must begin expending funds for all eligible individuals under the specified category before January 1, 2026, to qualify.

**Dollar Amounts:** No specific dollar amounts are stated in this section.

**Downstream Effects:** States that delay Medicaid expansion or coverage expenditures for the specified population beyond January 1, 2026, will lose eligibility for enhanced federal Medicaid matching funds under this provision. This creates a fiscal incentive for states to expand coverage sooner.

sections.section: SEC. 71115. PROVIDER TAXES.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Stopping Abusive Financing Practices
sections.summary:
1. **Policy Changes**:
   - Revises the "hold harmless" threshold for broad-based health care-related taxes under Medicaid starting FY 2027.
   - Replaces the fixed 6% threshold with a variable "applicable percent" based on state Medicaid expansion status and tax status as of enactment.
   - For non-expansion states:
     - If a qualifying tax is in place and within threshold at enactment, the applicable percent is the Secretary-determined rate.
     - If no qualifying tax exists at enactment, the applicable percent is 0%.
   - For expansion states:
     - If a qualifying tax is in place and within threshold at enactment, the applicable percent is the lesser of the Secretary-determined rate or a declining statutory cap.
     - If no qualifying tax exists at enactment, the applicable percent is 0%.
   - Statutory cap for expansion states:
     - FY 2028: 5.5%
     - FY 2029: 5.0%
     - FY 2030: 4.5%
     - FY 2031: 4.0%
     - FY 2032 and beyond: 3.5%
   - Grandfathers certain taxes in expansion states that meet specific criteria, allowing them to retain their Secretary-determined applicable percent.

2. **Dollar Amounts**:
   - $20,000,000 appropriated in FY 2026 to CMS for implementation, available until expended.

3. **Downstream Effects**:
   - Limits states' ability to finance Medicaid through provider taxes by reducing the allowable threshold over time, particularly for expansion states.
   - May reduce federal Medicaid matching funds for states relying on provider taxes above new thresholds.
   - Encourages states to reassess or restructure existing provider tax schemes to remain compliant.
   - Could create fiscal pressure on expansion states with high provider tax reliance.

sections.section: SEC. 71116. STATE DIRECTED PAYMENTS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Stopping Abusive Financing Practices
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Revises 42 CFR 438.6(c)(2)(iii) to cap Medicaid managed care directed payments for services rendered during rating periods starting on or after enactment.
- For Medicaid expansion states (covering ACA adult group with minimum essential coverage), payment cap is 100% of the Medicare rate (or Medicaid rate if no Medicare rate exists).
- For non-expansion states, payment cap is 110% of the Medicare rate (or Medicaid rate if no Medicare rate exists).
- Grandfathers certain pre-approved or submitted payments made before May 1, 2025, or for rural hospitals before enactment, allowing them to phase down by 10 percentage points annually starting January 1, 2028, until they meet the new cap.
- States that newly expand Medicaid post-enactment will be subject to the 100% Medicare rate cap immediately for services rendered after enactment.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- $7 million appropriated annually from FY2026 through FY2033 to implement the section, available until expended.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Limits state flexibility in setting Medicaid managed care directed payments, potentially reducing supplemental payments to providers.
- Creates financial incentives for states to expand Medicaid to access more favorable payment caps.
- Gradual reduction in above-cap payments for grandfathered arrangements may impact provider revenue, especially for rural hospitals.
- Could lead to payment standardization across states and alignment with Medicare rates.

sections.section: SEC. 71117. REQUIREMENTS REGARDING WAIVER OF UNIFORM TAX REQUIREMENT FOR MEDICAID PROVIDER TAX.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Stopping Abusive Financing Practices
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Clarifies that a health care-related tax is not "generally redistributive" (and thus potentially impermissible under Medicaid financing rules) if:
  - Taxpayers or tax rate groups with a lower share of Medicaid-related taxable units are taxed at a lower rate than those with a higher share.
  - Taxpayers or tax rate groups are taxed at a higher rate based on Medicaid-related units than on non-Medicaid-related units.
  - The tax structure uses indirect descriptors (e.g., payment terminology) to achieve the same discriminatory effect.
- Adds definitions for:
  - "Medicaid taxable unit" (e.g., Medicaid bed days, revenue, claims, or expenditures).
  - "Non-Medicaid taxable unit" (e.g., non-Medicaid bed days, revenue, claims, or expenditures).
  - "Tax rate group" (entities within a permissible class taxed at the same rate).

2. Dollar Amounts:
- No specific dollar amounts are included in this section.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Restricts states from structuring provider taxes in a way that disproportionately burdens providers serving Medicaid patients, potentially reducing states' ability to generate matching federal Medicaid funds through provider taxes.
- May require states to revise existing health care-related tax structures to comply with the clarified definitions and avoid federal disallowances.
- Applies only to the 50 states and D.C., not U.S. territories.
- Changes take effect upon enactment, with a Secretary-determined transition period of up to three fiscal years.

sections.section: SEC. 71118. REQUIRING BUDGET NEUTRALITY FOR MEDICAID DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS UNDER SECTION 1115.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter C--Stopping Abusive Financing Practices
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Effective January 1, 2027, the Secretary of HHS may not approve new, renewed, or amended Medicaid demonstration projects under Section 1115 unless the CMS Chief Actuary certifies that the project will not increase federal expenditures compared to baseline Medicaid spending.
- Expenditures for services or populations that could otherwise be covered under the State Medicaid plan or other Title XIX authority are to be treated as baseline expenditures, even if delivered differently under the demonstration.
- If a demonstration project results in lower expenditures than the baseline during its approval period, the Secretary must define a methodology to account for those savings in future project approval periods.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- $5 million is appropriated for each of FY 2026 and FY 2027 to CMS for implementation, with funds available until expended.

3. Downstream Effects:
- Stricter budget neutrality requirements may limit state flexibility in designing Medicaid demonstration projects.
- States may face increased actuarial and administrative burdens to obtain certification.
- Potential reduction in approval of cost-increasing demonstration projects.
- Savings from demonstration projects may influence future funding baselines, potentially reducing federal support in subsequent periods.

sections.section: SEC. 71119. REQUIREMENT FOR STATES TO ESTABLISH MEDICAID COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT REQUIREMENTS FOR CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter D--Increasing Personal Accountability
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
- Establishes a mandatory Medicaid community engagement (work/community service/education) requirement for “applicable individuals” aged 19–64, effective no later than Q1 2027, unless exempted.
- Compliance requires 80 hours/month of qualifying activities or equivalent income.
- States may verify compliance at redetermination or more frequently.
- Exemptions include individuals who are pregnant, disabled, medically frail, caregivers, veterans with total disability, in substance abuse treatment, or under age 19, among others.
- States must provide 30-day notice and opportunity to cure noncompliance before denial or disenrollment.
- States must conduct outreach and use ex parte verification methods where possible.
- States cannot waive the requirement under Section 1115 waivers.
- States may request a temporary exemption from implementation through December 31, 2028, based on good faith efforts and reporting.
- Prohibits contractors with financial ties to Medicaid managed care entities from determining compliance.

2. Dollar Amounts:
- $100 million appropriated in FY2026 for formula-based state grants to establish eligibility systems.
- $100 million appropriated in FY2026 for equal distribution grants to states for the same purpose.
- $200 million appropriated in FY2026 to CMS for implementation support.
- All funds remain available until expended.

3. Downstream Effects:
- States must build or upgrade systems to track and verify community engagement.
- Noncompliant individuals may lose Medicaid coverage unless they qualify for another eligibility category.
- Increased administrative burden on states for outreach, verification, and appeals.
- Potential reduction in Medicaid enrollment among non-exempt adults failing to meet requirements.
- CMS oversight increases, including rulemaking by June 1, 2026, and monitoring of state compliance and exemptions.

sections.section: SEC. 71120. MODIFYING COST SHARING REQUIREMENTS FOR CERTAIN EXPANSION INDIVIDUALS UNDER THE MEDICAID PROGRAM.
sections.title: TITLE VII--FINANCE
sections.subtitle: Subtitle B--Health
sections.chapter: CHAPTER 1--MEDICAID
sections.subchapter: Subchapter D--Increasing Personal Accountability
sections.summary:
1. Policy Changes:
